HEADLINE: Charity Begins At the Board. Just Ask A.I.G.

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
IT has to have been a bewildering few weeks for Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group. One minute his company is producing record revenues and he is high-fiving himself on Congress's passage of tort reform, one of his passions. The next minute he is dumped from the company he has run for almost 40 years and finds himself facing an under-oath interview with prosecutors from the Justice Department, Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general's office, the same guys he used to bully on a regular basis.
 You almost feel sorry for the man. Exalted for so long, he forgot what it was like to be questioned. 
 It is impossible to get inside someone else's head, of course, but one of the most puzzling aspects of Mr. Greenberg's downfall, to him at least, might have been the role his 10 outside directors played in it. The people who ultimately pushed him from power were, after all, his hand-picked colleagues, people who had been with him, in some cases, for more than a decade. Many of them were also people he encountered in other high-powered orbits, and he donated generously to their favorite causes. 
 A.I.G.'s directors include M. Bernard Aidinoff, retired partner at Sullivan & Cromwell; Pei-yuan Chia, retired vice chairman of Citicorp; Marshall A. Cohen, former chief executive of the Molson Companies, a Canadian brewer; William S. Cohen, the former senator and secretary of defense; Martin S. Feldstein, the Harvard economist who is mentioned as a possible successor to Alan Greenspan.
 Joining those five luminaries are Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History in New York; Carla A. Hills, former United States trade representative; Frank J. Hoenemeyer, retired vice chairman of the Prudential Insurance Company of America; Richard C. Holbrooke, former ambassador to the United Nations; and Frank G. Zarb, former chairman of the Nasdaq stock market and senior adviser to Hellman & Friedman, a private investment firm. 
 Clearly a star-studded board. 
 And a collegial one, too. Besides their common interests in the workings of A.I.G., many of the outside directors also share Mr. Greenberg's interest in world affairs. Half are directors or members with Mr. Greenberg at the Council on Foreign Relations, an independent policy group. 
 Over the years, Mr. Greenberg connected with many of his outside directors in another way: by making big donations through the Starr Foundation, a nonprofit organization he controls, to institutions that some A.I.G. directors led or belonged to. 
 Contributions to such outfits surpassed $44 million from 1998 to 2003, the most recent figures available. (The information for 1999 was incomplete.) This is a sizable sum, to be sure. Still, it is less than 5 percent of the donations that Starr has made during the five years for which public figures are available. 
 The Starr Foundation was created by C.V. Starr, the founder of A.I.G., in his will. According to the most recent filing, it had roughly $3.6 billion in assets, mostly in A.I.G. shares. It is a major contributor to education: 34 percent of the $190 million it distributed in 2003 went to academic scholarships. The rest went to cultural and charitable institutions like Carnegie Hall, the Children's Aid Society and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. It also made donations to New York Times Company Foundation projects.
 Florence A. Davis is president of the Starr foundation, but Mr. Greenberg is its chairman and, according to the filing, devotes 200 hours a year to its business. Ms. Davis did not return a phone call seeking comment. Mr. Greenberg, through his lawyer, declined to comment.
 One of the biggest recipients of Starr funds is the Asia Society, which aims to educate Americans about Asia. In 2003, Starr paid $2.6 million to the society, of which Mr. Greenberg is a trustee. Mr. Holbrooke is both a trustee and the chairman of the society's executive committee. 
 Large contributions -- more than $26 million -- have also gone to the American Museum of Natural History, where Ms. Futter is president. The foundation gave the museum $1 million in 1998; Ms. Futter joined the A.I.G. board the next year. In 2000, Starr contributed $100,000, but it gave an astounding $25.1 million in 2001. An additional $100,000 came the museum's way in 2003.
 Groups that Ms. Hills has been associated with have also received considerable donations from Starr. The National Committee on U.S.-China Relations received a total of $1.85 million during the period, while the Institute for International Economics got $3.2 million. The Trilateral Commission received $120,000.
 The Brookings Institution, which counts Mr. Aidinoff as a council member, received $1.95 million from Starr during the period. And the Council on Foreign Relations received almost $7 million. 
 THEN there is Mr. Feldstein's National Bureau of Economic Research, which has received about $3 million since 1998. The William S. Cohen Center for International Policy and Commerce, at the University of Maine, received a total of $1 million in 1999 and 2000, four years before Mr. Cohen joined the A.I.G. board.
 Finally, the Frank G. Zarb School of Business at Hofstra University took in $675,000 in 2003; Mr. Zarb joined the A.I.G board in 2001. 
 Chris Winans, an A.I.G. spokesman, said, ''The board's decisive actions have demonstrated its strong independence.'' He added that Mr. Zarb had no knowledge of any donations that the Starr Foundation made to the Frank G. Zarb School of Business since Mr. Zarb joined the A.I.G. board. None of the other independent directors who are connected to groups that received Starr donations would comment. 
 A.I.G., in its most recent proxy statement, says directors can be considered independent as long as contributions to the nonprofit organization they run do not exceed $1 million or 2 percent of the charitable organization's gross revenues for the most recent year. 
 The donations to Mr. Feldstein's National Bureau of Economic Research did exceed those amounts. But the proxy said the board, on the recommendation of the nominating and corporate governance committee, had determined that the contributions did not ''impair'' his independence. The proxy also said Mr. Feldstein had advised the committee that there was ''no present intention to seek additional funding for the bureau from the Starr Foundation.''
 Did the foundation's contributions to the directors' favored organizations influence them as the recent crisis unfolded at A.I.G.? None of the directors would comment on that. 
 Still, human nature being what it is, the contributions could not possibly have made the directors' decision to defenestrate Mr. Greenberg any easier. 
 The Starr Foundation is clearly doing crucial work in the arts, medicine and education. But shareholders have a right to wonder if all those donations to the directors' favorite charities are clouding their judgment.

HEADLINE: Three Hundred Million Maniacs

BYLINE: By William Saletan. 
William Saletan writes the Human Nature column for Slate. He is the author of ''Bearing Right: How Conservatives Won the Abortion War.''

 BODY:

AMERICAN MANIA
When More Is Not Enough.
By Peter C. Whybrow.
338 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

THE HYPOMANIC EDGE
The Link Between (a Little) Craziness
and (a Lot of) Success in America.
By John D. Gartner.
354 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.
 A CENTURY ago, a proponent of free markets might have produced admiring biographies of the captains of industry. A populist critic might have issued a manifesto. Today, argument and interpretation won't do. To win an economic debate in our age of incredulity, you need a higher authority: science. That's the authority asserted by John D. Gartner, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University Medical School, and Peter C. Whybrow, the director of the Neuropsychiatric Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles, whose new books invoke monkey research, human biology and case studies in business psychology to substantiate their views of the economy. In a delightful twist of the marketplace of ideas, the collision of those views -- and of their appeals to science -- yields a felicitous result: a case study in the psychology of psychologists.
 Gartner concedes he can be high-strung. A few years ago, he was a passionate technology investor -- in effect, he says, a messianic follower. He ''hooted like an elated primate'' when his portfolio soared. He favors italics and exclamation points. He calls things ''stunning'' and ''enormous.'' He argues that there is an American temperament that has made the nation the world's most successful. He loves the market that ''liberated'' entrepreneurs. He calls a cleaning job at Wal-Mart ''the first rung of the American ladder.'' Whybrow is more wary. He fondly recalls the rural village where he farmed a bit as his daughters grew up. He distrusts America's ''flouting of international agreements'' on nuclear weapons and the environment. He laments cuts in government spending on schools and social services. He argues that a ''Fast New World'' of nonstop global commerce is making us ill. He blames Wal-Mart, Disney and McDonald's.
 Both men are talking about a condition called hypomania, characterized by a persistent high that is short of the full-blown mania of manic-depression (or bipolar disorder) and not routinely followed by a depressive low. And both present themselves as pure scientists. Gartner says his profiles of dead entrepreneurs, ''written by a psychologist,'' are ''clinical case histories that illustrate hypomania in action.'' Whybrow insists his politics play ''no part in my concern. What does is my growing awareness, as a practicing psychiatrist and a behavioral scientist, that American culture is becoming detached from some fundamental truths about human behavior.''
 In Gartner's case, the promise of scientific rigor soon melts. He says he has interviewed 10 dot-com C.E.O.'s, and each fits his criteria for hypomania. ''One hundred percent of the entrepreneurs I interviewed were hypomanic! This couldn't be chance,'' he exults. ''It felt as if I had tested the waters with my little pilot study and been hit with a tidal wave.''
 To verify that mania and hypomania are ''radically different,'' Gartner consults the psychiatrist's bible, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. But the manual says the diagnostic criteria are virtually identical, so he turns to surveys, hoping to prove that hypomania is widespread. The surveys indicate only one in 1,000 people is hypomanic, so Gartner broadens the criteria, arguing that anyone who admits to having gone through ''a period of greatly increased energy'' is hypomanic. He presents his list of hypomanic criteria to an expert on business leaders. The expert says he's never seen any scholarly literature on these criteria and suggests a different diagnosis. Gartner dismisses it. At every turn, he's amazed that nobody else sees the ''invisible'' thread of hypomania.
 Whybrow sticks closer to the literature. Hypomania is ''the second stage of a developing mania,'' he explains. An ordinary psychiatrist would apply this diagnosis to one patient at a time, but Whybrow wants to heal society. So he interprets the Internet boom and bust as collective manic depression: excitement, risk, irrational exuberance, megalomania, profligate spending, collapse, confusion, reflection, anxiety. ''Greed and envy had become a national disease,'' he writes, noting that in 1999, Amazon lost $350 million, and by 2002, economists were ''burying'' the company. Why does the story have to end in 2002? Because by the end of 2003, the company was turning a profit.
 This is the danger of diagnosing a whole society: you start selecting theories to fit the evidence, but you end up selecting evidence to fit the theory. Whybrow makes the economy look more manic than it is by devoting dozens of pages to the Internet bubble; in choosing business leaders to study, Gartner tellingly devotes none. Gartner profiles only one living entrepreneur, Craig Venter, who sequenced the human genome. The genome project suits Gartner's theory. It covers the same period as the Internet bubble but yields a more impressive legacy. Hypomania works! Still, to make his case, Gartner has to look past Venter's manic dysfunctions -- reckless spending, self-destructive abrasiveness, bad decisions, revisionism -- and credit him for the labor and ideas of others: the aide who organized Venter's ''chaos''; the colleague who figured out how to shortcut the sequencing job; the government researchers whose data Venter mined. Venter was still the man behind it all, says Gartner, because ''a genius is someone who acts on a good idea when he hears one.''
 Both authors think immigrant vitality drives America's economy and is probably genetic. But their agreement ends there. Gartner, like the 19th-century social Darwinists, assumes our form of capitalism is natural, not cultural. ''I would attribute the number of hours Americans work to what I call the 'immigrant work drive,' an internal biological compulsion passed from parent to child through their hypomanic genes,'' he writes. The entrepreneurial ferocity others call the ''American character'' is really a genetically based ''American temperament,'' he asserts.
 Whybrow disagrees. Like 19th-century critics of capitalism, he sees our economy as a recent perversion of nature. Temperament and character are different, he argues. Genes shape temperament, but culture shapes character. American energy and self-interest may be innate, but our crazy society converts our temperament into crazy work hours. We've replaced the communities and local markets that once circumscribed our material craving with an impersonal global economy that inflames our craving into mania. Our culture is misdirecting our biology -- and destroying it. We're becoming sleep-deprived, anxious and fat.
 Capitalism's manic energy has made us wealthier, but at a price. Gartner compares it to the sickle cell gene carried by many Africans. Most carriers get one copy of the gene, which protects them from malaria. But some get two copies, which cause sickle cell anemia. Is the gene good? That depends on which disease worries you more. In the case of mania, Gartner likes the deal. ''The cold truth is that humanity has a large supply of people to waste, and in the calculus of evolution a bunch of troublemakers who come to no good are a fair price for a Meriwether Lewis or a Craig Venter,'' he writes. To Whybrow, the price is too high. Too many people are exploited, neglected, indebted, time-starved and sick.
 Which author is right? Look at their behavior. One says hypomania is dangerous. His grandiosity skews his reporting a bit, but his analysis is coherent and documented. The other says hypomania is productive. He throws together a few entertaining minibiographies, leaps to radical genetic conclusions with minimal evidence and disregards negative feedback. His inquiry, such as it is, answers itself. If hypomania does for us what it does for its diagnostic defenders, we're in trouble.

HEADLINE: In Westchester, Employers and Workers Feeling the Pain of a Bus Strike

BYLINE: By MAREK FUCHS

 BODY:
As the Bee-Line bus strike grinds through its sixth week, Westchester County businesses whose employees depend on buses are growing increasingly exasperated trying to get workers to their jobs.
 At the Atlanta Bread Company in White Plains, the owner, Eric Hartstein, said he has had to open at 8 a.m., an hour and a half later than usual, sacrificing some of his coffee-and-bagel business, because all but one of his 35 employees depend on buses to get to work. 
 At Monroe College in New Rochelle, cheerleaders were scarce at a recent basketball playoff game because several members of the squad had to work the cash registers at a Stop & Shop supermarket when their co-workers who depend on buses had no way to get to work. 
 And White Plains Hospital Center, where more than a quarter of its 1,400 workers normally ride a bus to work, is using every nonemergency vehicle in its fleet to ferry employees to work, some from across the Hudson River. ''It's been a strain, a significant challenge,'' said Richard P. Biondi, vice president for development and community affairs, observing that the hospital is a 24-hour-a-day operation. 
 Bee-Line's 568 striking workers, members of Local 100 of the Transit Workers Union, walked off their jobs on March 3 over a number of issues, primarily the age at which employees can retire and receive a full pension. About 50,000 people rode the bus every day, two-thirds to get to work, where most earn less than $35,000 a year, according to county officials. A federal mediator is trying to resolve the differences.
 Marsha Gordon, the president of the Business Council of Westchester, said that the effects of the strike have cut across all sectors of the economy. She said health care providers and nonprofit organizations have been particularly hard hit. 
 Susan Tolchin, the chief adviser to County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who has come under criticism for traveling to China on a trade mission during the strike, said small retailers have been hurt the worst, because of no-show employees and customers. 
 Mr. Hartstein, the Atlanta Bread Company owner, said he has been encouraging his employees to sleep at the homes of friends who live nearby, but the results have been disappointing. 
 ''Employees are showing up with their clothes a mess and in the same outfits.'' he said. ''It's not good for business.'' He added that his workers are ''constantly moaning about getting pay raises to pay for the cabs. It's been vicious.'' 
 Timothy C. Idoni, the mayor of New Rochelle, said that restaurants in particular have been hard hit. But he said that some businesses along North Street, a commercial strip, have been helped by the strike because hundreds of students from New Rochelle High School who normally take Bee-Line buses are now walking -- right down North Street on their way home. 
 ''The foot traffic has really increased, and some of the stores have been adding soda and candy to cater to the students,'' he said.
 Less lucky are merchants in retail centers like the Cross County Mall, which rely heavily on public bus traffic, Ms. Tolchin said. The county has recently been running buses for older residents to such places. The county is also starting a program to compensate welfare recipients and the working poor for the cost of getting to work.
 Commuters who take Metro-North to White Plains and then ride a bus to one of the many office parks along the Interstate 287 corridor have also been disrupted by the strike. 
 Some businesses and property managers have rented vans to shuttle workers from train stations. Ellen Lynch, the managing director of East Ridge Properties, with four office parks, has vans running loops during commuter-rush periods. 
 But in this county, where unemployment hovers at only 4 percent, not all businesses have been touched by the strike. 
 David Logan, president of the board of Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, said that nearly all his employees, from diggers to grounds workers, drive cars. 
 And Pat Riso, a spokesman for Kraft Foods in Tarrytown, said that employees who usually take the bus have found other modes of transportation.
 But most employers, said Cloey Sepe, the president of the Mount Vernon Chamber of Commerce, ''are just struggling, and many employees are just taking a lot of sick days.''
 Ms. Gordon of the Business Council of Westchester said, ''The longer this goes on, the more frustrated people are getting.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: With Bee-Line workers on strike, Horace Lewis, left, of the Bronx and Alvin Williams of Queens arrived by van Friday at the Metro-North station in White Plains. (Photo by Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Next Investing Frontier: Lower Fees

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, the mutual fund industry faced few questions about what it charged investors. There was the occasional outburst from regulators involving high-pressure salesmanship but almost nobody complained about advisory fees for managing portfolios or the multiple costs of constant trading.
 That has changed. These days, sales methods are not so much in question -- other than the practice of using fund assets to pay for marketing and distribution -- but recurring operational fees have become a major subject of scrutiny.
 In the process, some investors have become disenchanted with mutual funds, recognizing the toll that fees take on performance. Nevertheless, fees have been falling significantly. Shareholders paid 1.25 percent of assets in stock and hybrid funds, on average, in 2003, including hefty but indirect sales commissions, down from 1.35 percent in 1998, and 2.05 percent in both 1988 and 1983, according to sales-weighted figures provided by the Investment Company Institute, the industry's trade group. 
 Investors have noticed. Last year, 76.2 percent of net new cash flow into stock funds went to those with total expense ratios of 1 percent or less. That compares with 47.6 percent in 1995.
 One impetus for the closer look at costs, besides the sobered investment climate since the Internet bubble burst, is the belated realization that small differences in fees make huge differences in results when compounded over many decades.
 Another is low-cost competition from a new product: index funds that can be traded on exchanges.
 Then came the campaign against late trading and market timing by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. That put shoddy industry practices on public view and led to settlements in which several companies cut fees. (Late trading involves receiving a given day's fund price for orders placed after the close of trading that day. Market timing is the practice of short-term trading in fund shares to exploit market-moving news.) ''Improper trading and the exorbitant fees charged are both consequences of a governance structure that permitted managers to enrich themselves at the expense of investors,'' Mr. Spitzer told Congress in November 2003. 
 The Spitzer campaign focused on fund families including Alliance Capital Management, Massachusetts Financial Services, Putnam Investments, Janus Capital Group and Strong Financial. So far, in the opinion of some fund officials, consultants and critics, the campaign has had relatively little effect on fees elsewhere in the industry. 
 ''You're seeing token concessions here and there that suggest they're restructuring their fees,'' said Gordon Daisley III, a financial adviser and associate vice president at Morgan Stanley in Washington. And Stephen Norwitz, a vice president at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, said the Spitzer campaign had not had ''a widespread impact in the industry.'' 
 John C. Bogle, the founder of Vanguard and a persistent critic of fund managers, said that Mr. Spitzer's efforts had reinforced competitive pressures acting to bring down costs -- although not enough to seriously impair the industry's hefty profits. Mr. Bogle estimates that the industry collects about $63 billion in total fees each year and spends $27 billion on marketing and administration and $5 billion on managing portfolios.
 REFERRING to the remaining $31 billion, Mr. Bogle said, ''Profit margins in this business are extremely high, almost 50 percent.''
 In fact, the efforts of Mr. Spitzer and other regulators have led to some fee increases, such as the imposition of redemption fees on funds with relatively illiquid portfolios, to discourage market timing. T. Rowe Price, which has not been the target of an investigation, has extended such fees to 401(k) accounts. In addition, sponsors of some new funds, realizing that they will likely be feeling pressure to reduce fees, may have initially set them a bit higher than they would have a decade or so ago. Still, the underlying downward trend seems unmistakable.
 Consider the decision last month by Fidelity Investments, the industry's biggest fund family, which since 2003 has levied no sales charges on funds sold directly to investors. It permanently limited the annual expenses of five of its domestic equity index funds to one-tenth of 1 percent. This is just over half the lowest comparable rate charged by the Vanguard Group, which has long boasted of its low costs.
 ''The index fund thing was thought out a long time ago'' as part of an integrated, customer-friendly brokerage, bond and advisory strategy, said Jeff Carney, president of Fidelity Personal Investments. ''It was long before Spitzer came on the scene.''
 He said index funds had become a commodity -- and were being priced accordingly.
 Russel Kinnel, director of mutual fund research at Morningstar, said: ''More investors have more low-cost options than ever before. In the index arena, we're seeing something close to a price war.''
 What's more, the chief enforcement official at the Securities and Exchange Commission, Stephen M. Cutler, has questioned why index funds in general charge a wide range of fees for similar, market-mimicking work.
 As of April 1, the Capital Research and Management Company, which sponsors the American Funds group, indefinitely waived 10 percent of its management fee on all 29 of its funds, doubling the reduction it began without fanfare last year.
 It said this action, which it estimated would save its investors about $200 million a year, or about $3 for a $10,000 investment in its biggest fund, reflected economies of scale. The group, whose expenses were already well below the industry average, has attracted huge amounts of fresh money in the last two years. 
 Increasing numbers of fund buyers have become more attentive to the price of fund investing, which they tended to dismiss as unimportant. That might have been rational when many funds gained 25 percent or more a year, as they did in the late 1990's, but costs loom larger when returns are modest.
 Many fund investors have also noticed that most professional managers underperform their benchmarks, and not entirely because of costs. That has prompted investors to wonder how much value these managers add. 
 Portfolio management and other operational expenses account for 70 percent, on average, of the fees levied on investors in stock funds, with distribution costs accounting for the rest, half of them under Rule 12b-1 of the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to the Investment Company Institute. 
 Investors are learning more about the impact of costs even though a majority pay for professional help in making investment selections from a proliferation of funds and classes of fund shares.
 ''There's study after study out there that show that cost is the primary determinant of fund performance,'' said John S. Woerth, a spokesman at Vanguard, which last year had an aggregate expense ratio of 0.23 percent, down from 0.54 percent in 1984. ''The message is starting to get out. Consumers are smart. They're beating a path to the low-cost providers.''
 Burton J. Greenwald, an independent fund consultant in Philadelphia, said that while antiterrorism legislation like the Patriot Act had added to industry costs because of more stringent reporting standards, limiting the ability to cut fees, the explosive increase in exchange-traded funds had pushed in the opposite direction. Last year, individual investors surpassed hedge funds and other institutions in total E.T.F. trading.
 ''The market forces are probably more important'' than Mr. Spitzer and other regulators, Mr. Greenwald said. ''There's real competition, especially from E.T.F.'s.'' 
 Recently, a handful of funds have even trimmed 12b-1 fees, which, in combination with the introduction of various classes of fund shares, have largely been substituted for front-end sales commissions, or loads. One such group is Hartford Mutual Funds, which on Nov. 1 cut the fees on Class A shares of its more than three dozen retail funds to 0.25 percent from 0.30 percent.
 In general, for funds sold with commissions, Class A shares carry front-end loads, Class B shares carry declining back-end loads prompted by redemptions and Class C shares charge a recurring annual percentage of an investor's account. 
 These fees, used mainly to pay brokers and financial advisers who market fund shares and for administrative services, are also under study by the S.E.C. 
 Last month, Putnam agreed to pay $40 million to settle S.E.C. accusations that it had failed to properly disclose that it used fund brokerage commissions rather than Putnam's own cash to compensate those who sold its shares. The S.E.C. has proposed to bar directed brokerage, as this practice is called. 
 Reflecting the settlement, the Dec. 31 semiannual report of Putnam's International Equity fund, for example, contains fresh detail about the fund's expenses, including dollar amounts, and data comparing the fund's portfolio turnover and risks with those of similar competitors. 
 ORIGINALLY, 12b-1 fees were envisioned as a temporary device to allow funds to reach viable size and were first adopted by no-load fund companies, which lacked a sales force. But now the fees, paid out of fund assets, compensate brokers and others who sell fund shares, and pay for advertising, and for the printing and mailing of prospectuses and sales literature to new investors. Even some funds closed to new investors charge 12b-1 fees. 
 But even if the visible impact of Mr. Spitzer's mutual fund campaign has been scattered, it nonetheless ''has been an unbelievable plus,'' Mr. Bogle said. In the end, he added, ''costs will have to come down for competitive reasons.''

HEADLINE: Oh, to Be in England Now That April's There

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER. 
E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
''We're just princesses, all of us,'' said Anita Summer, her clipped Cockney twang still pronounced 50 years after she left her native London. 
 Ms. Summer, a Westbury resident who was born in the East End, is a former regent of the Daughters of the British Empire's Westminster Abbey chapter, on Long Island. Like the other 42 members of the expatriate group, she continues to be infatuated with all things British. 
 ''We all love the royal family, with all their faults,'' said Ms. Summer, long ago a reporter for the Daily Mirror in London. ''We're all human. To err is human.'' 
 When the Queen Mother turned 100 in 2000, Ms. Summer's coterie of loyal subjects held a fund-raising party. They celebrated again for Queen Elizabeth's golden jubilee in 2003. ''I love America, but I love England, too,'' Ms. Summer said. ''It's where my heart is.''
 So at a recent luncheon meeting of the Westminster Abbey chapter, Ms. Summer discussed plans for a high tea April 17 at her home in honor of the marriage of Prince Charles to Camilla Parker Bowles. 
 ''Why not?'' Ms. Summer said. In fact, the only dissension in the British sisterhood swirled around whether Mrs. Parker Bowles should be allowed to become queen. 
 ''She obviously loves him,'' Ms. Summer said. ''They are getting on in years. Why not let them finish out their years together?'' 
 For the occasion, Ms. Summer promised that her basement would be decorated with Union Jacks and British memorabilia, including a water glass that Princess Margaret asked Ms. Summer to hold at a party in 1974. Ms. Summers, who was covering the event at the Waldorf-Astoria as a journalist, not only kept the glass, she never washed it. 
 ''Dress appropriately,'' she told the women gathered at the home of Victoria Crosby, the current regent, who lives in Glen Cove. ''Don't come in your usual shmattes. Dress like the last royal function you went to, with tiaras.''
 The devotees to the crown meet monthly at one another's homes and at restaurants on the Island. They tend to be a forgiving lot. For Christmas they had a luncheon at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn.
 ''They were all British, those malcontents,'' said Ms. Crosby, who grew up in Cheshire in the north of England, came to America at 19 for a job, quickly married an American and raised four sons on Colonial soil. She holds both British and United States citizenships. 
 The chapter, the largest of eight in New York State, is mainly a social organization but also raises money for the Victoria House in Ossining, one of four nursing homes supported by the 5,000 members of the Daughters of the British Empire nationwide, and for the British Garden being created in Manhattan in memory of the British victims of Sept. 11. 
 The nonprofit group was founded in 1909 for women of British birth or parentage. To qualify, Ms. Summer said, ''British blood should be flowing through their veins.''
 The Nassau-Suffolk chapter more than doubled in size after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997, when British expatriates were incensed that Queen Elizabeth was criticized for seeming cold and detached about the funeral. 
 ''Why is it that when J.F.K. was assassinated and Jackie Kennedy stood to attention with the children, everyone said how wonderful she was and how marvelous, and when our queen did the same thing she was criticized?'' Ms. Summer recalled asking at the time. 
 Two weeks ago Ms. Crosby mailed Prince Charles a flowery congratulatory card on his marriage that she bought for $3.69 at the Stop & Shop in Glen Cove. A quick reply stamped ''Royal Mail'' from the secretary of Clarence House, the prince's official residence, said the Prince of Wales and Mrs. Parker Bowles, were ''immensely touched'' by her kind words. 
 But Ms. Crosby's loyalty to the crown is even more evident. Her doorbell plays ''Rule Brittania,'' and her waterfront house is decorated like an English cottage, with a collection of Queen Victoria figurines and memorabilia on display. An autographed commissioning letter from the queen to a soldier hangs over the fireplace. Touristy mugs from Prince Charles's 1981 wedding to Diana and Princess Anne's 1973 wedding to Capt. Mark Phillips, along with a teapot with a picture of King Henry VIII and a model of a royal wedding coach, sit on the mantelpiece.
 Ms. Crosby, the poet laureate of Glen Cove and the director of the Morgan Park Summer Festival, said the women's common heritage drew them together. 
 ''As British women we feel a stronger attachment to our mother country since we left,'' Ms. Crosby said. ''We would move in different circles if we were in England.'' 
 As a young woman, Valerie McPhillips, 71, worked as a typist at Scotland Yard. In 1961, at the age of 26, she came to visit a cousin in Port Washington and stayed. She worked as a waitress for 30 years. Two years ago she joined the Daughters of the British Empire. 
 ''I love hearing the accent,'' Ms. McPhillips said, noting that their British inflections tend to get thicker when the members meet. ''It helps me get over my little homesickness.''
 The group includes a royal cook. Diane Kaiser of Rocky Point, an owner of Brown's Tavern in Locust Valley, was born in Scotland and worked as a chef for the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester at Kensington Palace from 1982 to 1985. 
 Lesley Pryde Haley, formerly a soprano with the English National Opera, hails from Australia but lived in London for five years before relocating to Sea Cliff a dozen years ago. She came to the luncheon to consider joining the group. 
 ''I'm from the colonies,'' Ms. Pryde Haley said. ''It used to be part of the British Empire.''
 Betty Cairns of Sea Cliff said that the British women had a different experience from other immigrants. ''We did not come to this country as refugees,'' she said. ''We didn't come for economic reasons or for religious persecution. We came for love.''
 When they get together, many of the women reminisce about their experiences during World War II. Inevitably, the talk turns to tea. 
 ''I defend this country to my last breath, but they can't make tea,'' said Ms. Summer, who strayed across Atlantic waters in 1955 after marrying an American she met in postwar Switzerland. ''When I first came here, I brought my English tea. It didn't taste the same, and I thought, what am I doing wrong? I am doing everything I should do. It finally dawned on me. American water and English tea are not a good marriage.''
 Ms. Summer said she now has her tea bags sent from Canada. 
 The women also swap British recipes, share jokes and chatter about the royal family. 
 ''We are really thrown together by chance,'' Ms. Summer said. ''We come together from all different parts of the empire. You could make friends, and you love and adore them, but they don't remember what happened during the worst air raid on London, or what happened when you were bombed out and you had to try on your gas mask.''
 Their connection to their motherland and to one another is strong. 
 ''You sing an old song, and they know the words,'' Ms. Summer said. ''It's just the fact that you are bound together by this intangible something called memory. And memory is wonderful.''

HEADLINE: The 48ers

BYLINE: By Kevin Mattson. 
Kevin Mattson is the Connor Study professor of contemporary history at Ohio University and the author, most recently, of ''When America Was Great.''

 BODY:

THE BEST YEAR
OF THEIR LIVES
Kennedy, Johnson, and Nixon
in 1948: Learning the Secrets
of Power.
By Lance Morrow.
312 pp. Basic Books. $26.
 SOMETHING has happened to the American presidency in recent years. We seem to have become used to hearing the most lurid details about the occupants of the highest office, not only about Jack Kennedy and Bill Clinton, but even about Abraham Lincoln allegedly loving other men and Thomas Jefferson in the slave quarters. So is it any surprise that a new book about three postwar presidents claims to document their ''deceit'' and ''political ruthlessness'' and ''pathological'' behavior? Kennedy, Richard Nixon and Lyndon Johnson had ''personality disorders,'' Lance Morrow argues in ''The Best Year of Their Lives.'' Today, he says, ''Nixon and Johnson would be accused of clinical paranoia'' and Kennedy of such a degree of ''personal recklessness'' as to call into question his ''moral sanity.''
 Morrow paints this psychic picture by going back to the late 1940's, when all three were emerging as major players on the national stage. This was a fateful time. In the popular imagination, 1948 may be remembered as a year of Ozzie-and-Harriet complacency, when America stood supreme in the world, its economy coasting into prosperity. But it was also very much a period of anxiety, with worries about the bomb, the cold war and domestic subversion. American culture reflected this darkness in film noir, and in Whittaker Chambers's pessimistic writing for Time (and, more important, I'd argue, in the popularity of Reinhold Niebuhr's gloomy theology). The movie Morrow snatches for his title, ''The Best Years of Our Lives'' (actually released in 1946), shows G.I.'s bewildered by a transition from war's brutality to normalcy. 
 For Morrow, storm clouds hover over each man's public steps that year. Nixon's ''political opportunity'' came with the controversy he generated by helping Chambers make his case that Alger Hiss, Ivy Leagued and privileged, was a spy deceiving the American people. Johnson's came when he ran for senator and lied about his opponent, Coke Stevenson, while hiding details about his own campaign finances. As for Kennedy, 1948 was the year he took to lying about his health (while seducing nearly every woman in his path). Detailing secrecy and ruthlessness, Morrow, a journalist, a professor at Boston University and the author of six other books, draws lines from 1948 to the Bay of Pigs, Vietnam and Watergate.
 Darkness can turn hilarious in this tale, mostly through Morrow's funny stories about Nixon's awkwardness and Johnson's grossness. Traveling in an elevator with the interviewer David Frost, Nixon thought he could break the ice by asking: ''So, David. Did you do any fornicating over the weekend?'' There's the comical way Nixon bounced up and down, watching ''Around the World in Eighty Days,'' exclaiming: ''Watch! Here comes the elephant!'' Johnson demonstrated his infantile manners when he forced his advisers to ''confer with him while he sat on the toilet.''
 Morrow's a good writer and storyteller. But at times he overreaches. A comparison between Nixon and the actress Lana Turner -- two Californians who were ruthless and withdrawn -- goes on much too long. More troubling is Morrow's psychologizing. Nixon here is an ''anxious good little boy interrogating his mother's gaze for approval or disapproval.'' And ''if God had an id,'' Morrow explains, ''that was where Lyndon Johnson came from.'' In Morrow's reading, the psychological makeup of his three subjects seems almost to predetermine later events -- Vietnam and Watergate especially. But this flattens out the dynamic of history.
 Although ''The Best Year of Their Lives'' lacks new details, newness isn't everything, and the book succeeds in drawing together three fascinating characters into an illuminating historical intersection. You don't have to agree with all of Morrow's interpretations to be entertained by his lively treatment of three crucial figures during an important time in American history.

HEADLINE: A Tax Increase That Bush Didn't Mention

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
CYNICS have long predicted that the Bush administration, plagued by budget deficits, will eventually start raising taxes. But now it is becoming clear how it would do so: the alternative minimum tax.
 Baffling in its complexity and often bizarre in its impact, the alternative minimum tax is a giant undeclared tax increase that will ensnare tens of millions of moderate-income families in the next several years.
 It was created in 1969 to prevent the very rich from using tax deductions to avoid paying a fair share of taxes. But when the deadline for filing income tax returns arrives on Friday, the alternative minimum tax will require 2.9 million families to pay an average of about $6,000 more than what they would owe under traditional calculations 
 That is just the start. If current law remains unchanged, the alternative minimum tax is expected to wring an extra $33.9 billion from 18 million households in 2006. In 2010, it will rake in an additional $100 billion, and by 2015 an extra $200 billion.
 Make no mistake: no one says they want that to happen. But it is one thing to rein in or eliminate the tax itself, and an entirely different matter to give up the money that it would generate.
 President Bush has promised to fix the alternative minimum tax as part a fundamental overhaul of the tax code, and he has ordered a bipartisan advisory panel to come up with recommendations by the end of July. 
 But in giving the panel its marching orders, White House officials made it clear that they are counting on the extra money regardless of what happens to the alternative tax. Under the president's instructions, the panel's recommendations on addressing the alternative minimum tax are supposed to be ''revenue neutral,'' neither raising nor lowering taxes, and to assume that his income-tax cuts will be made permanent rather than expire in 2010, as required under current law.
 Making those ordinary income-tax cuts permanent would reduce the amount of available revenue by about $1.8 trillion over 10 years. But White House officials told the panel that any change to reduce or eliminate the alternative minimum tax would have to be offset by higher taxes someplace else.
 ''My understanding is that any reform in the A.M.T. that loses money would have to be made up with offsetting revenue,'' said Elizabeth Garrett, a panel member and a professor of law at the University of Southern California.
 Jeffrey F. Kupfer, executive director of the tax panel and a former Treasury official, confirmed that interpretation. ''Our mandate is to be revenue-neutral, and we are interpreting that with respect to the president's policy baseline, which does not include a permanent fix to the A.M.T.,'' he said in an interview last week.
 Tax experts have long complained that the alternative minimum tax is a ''stealth tax increase,'' one that Congress never intended and that is likely to catch millions of taxpayers by surprise. But a tax increase through tax reform could be even stealthier. If the alternative tax is reduced, the offsetting revenue increases are likely to be buried in so many other changes that most people would never know what hit them.
 Seen or unseen, the looming tax increases are almost as large as the president's tax cuts. Leonard E. Burman, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, estimated that the government would have to raise ordinary income tax rates substantially in every bracket to offset the money lost in each bracket by the elimination of the alternative minimum tax. People in today's 28 percent bracket, for example, would have to pay a top rate of 35 percent. Those who now pay a top rate of 33 percent would pay 41.4 percent.
 ''The A.M.T. is a huge tax increase built into current law,'' Mr. Burman said. ''What the current law assumes is that over time we move to a tax that is much less progressive, that has atrocious marriage penalties and penalizes people with children who live in high-tax states.''
 Taylor Griffin, a spokesman for the Treasury Department, said the administration's goal was to prevent a hidden tax increase by replacing the alternative tax with something that was easier to understand and more predictable. ''What we are trying to do is prevent a stealth tax that sneaks up on you,'' he said. ''If we don't do something, millions of Americans will be facing unanticipated tax increases.''
 The alternative minimum tax is similar in some ways to a flat tax that blocks people from using most of the big deductions that reduce their taxable income under the normal rules. A married couple with a gross income of $100,000, for example, must first calculate its tax bill the traditional way, then again under the A.M.T. In the alternative calculation, the couple gets to exclude $58,000 from taxation, but it must also strip out all the personal exemptions and most itemized deductions.
 The prohibited deductions include those for state and local taxes, medical expenses, employee business expenses and interest on home-equity loans. The A.M.T. would then apply a flat tax of 26 percent (28 percent for couples who earn more than $175,000). The couple must pay whichever is higher, the tax calculated under the traditional method or the one under the A.M.T.
 The huge looming tax increase is caused by two things. The first is that the exclusion level for the alternative minimum tax is not adjusted for inflation, so the tax affects more people each year as nominal incomes go up. The second, paradoxically, stems from Mr. Bush's tax cuts of 2001 and 2003. 
 Those cuts reduced regular tax rates at all income levels but did not change the alternative minimum tax. At the same time, some of the cuts came in the form of expanded deductions -- the child tax credit, child care tax credits and bigger exemptions for married couples -- that are not allowed under the alternative formula.
 The effect of making Mr. Bush's ordinary income tax cuts permanent would be significant. Mr. Burman, at the Urban Institute, estimated that the alternative minimum tax would generate about $69.2 billion in extra tax revenue in 2015 if the president's income tax cuts expired on schedule. But if the White House persuaded Congress to make the cuts permanent, the alternative minimum tax would raise a staggering $200.8 billion in that one year.
 If the A.M.T. itself is pared back, how would that tax increase show up in practice? The possibilities are almost limitless, from higher tax rates for everybody to the abolition of popular tax deductions.
 Administration officials are almost certain to insist that any tax reform result in lower tax rates and fewer deductions. Many Republicans long for a flat tax or a national sales tax, but that would mean abolishing or reducing sacred cows like the tax deduction for mortgage interest.
 A potential trade-off, but a politically explosive one, would be to eliminate deductions for state and local taxes, which cost the Treasury about $40 billion a year and are a big reason that many people become subject to the alternative tax. But getting rid of those deductions would cause howls of protest in Democratic-leaning states like New York and California, which tend to have above-average tax burdens.
 Thus far, the issues have been so tangled and vexing that both the White House and Congress have simply opted to block increases in the alternative minimum tax with one-year and two-year patches.
 But that will become expensive. By about 2008, Mr. Burman estimates, the alternative minimum tax will generate so much money that it would be cheaper to abolish the regular income tax.

HEADLINE: Gauging That Other Company Asset: Its Reputation

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS regulatory issues keep troubling Wall Street, some investors are beginning to wonder: Are sound business ethics not only a sign of a morally good company, but of a good investment as well?
 Jim Huguet certainly thinks so. At the very least, Mr. Huguet, the president of Great Companies L.L.C., a money management firm based in Clearwater, Fla., argues that sticking with companies with sound ethical practices, including transparency, accountability and a shareholder-friendly corporate governance structure, is a good way to avoid land mines in your portfolio. 
 ''This is not about feeling good about doing the right thing,'' said Mr. Huguet, whose firm oversees $1.3 billion in assets. ''It's about returns and protecting those returns.''
 The list of companies whose shares have been battered amid accusations of wrongdoing is a who's who of widely held stocks. Among the latest victims has been the insurance giant American International Group, whose stock is down 21 percent this year. 
 A.I.G. is being investigated by regulators over transactions that may have masked the company's financial health. A.I.G.'s longtime chairman and chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, was forced to step down as a result of the controversy. 
 But it's not just A.I.G. The shares of the Marsh & McLennan Companies are off 36 percent over the 12 months; in late January, it agreed to settle a lawsuit by regulators accusing it of cheating customers by rigging prices and steering business to insurers in exchange for incentive payments. 
 And last fall, regulators in Japan ordered Citigroup to suspend its private banking operations there because of violations of the country's banking laws. Citigroup stock is down 12 percent over the last 12 months. Paying attention to a company's behavior is a strategy to reduce risk. ''The lesson here is to treat and research corporate governance issues like any other fundamental,'' said Andrew Metrick, an associate finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
 Moreover, two academic studies conclude that investors appear to attach a good-citizenship premium to companies with solid governance structures and policies.
 One of those studies, published by Professor Metrick with Paul A. Gompers and Joy L. Ishii of Harvard in 2003, looked at the corporate governance attributes of roughly 1,500 companies from September 1990 to December 1999. It found that companies with strong shareholder rights provisions tended to exhibit higher profitability and sales growth, among other things.
 Companies that scored well on corporate governance issues also had higher Q ratios. This is an iteration of a statistical measure developed by James Tobin, the Nobel laureate economist; in this case it divides the market value of a company by its book value.
 Companies with good governance practices were rewarded with higher market values relative to their tangible assets than companies that scored poorly. ''There is a premium associated with good governance as far as we measured it,'' Professor Metrick said.
 A more recent study, a working paper released last year by Lawrence D. Brown, an accounting professor at Georgia State University and Marcus L. Caylor, a graduate student at the university, similarly found that investors were paying higher prices for companies with good governance.
 The Georgia State research found that some governance practices that are considered shareholder-friendly don't correlate with good fundamentals. For instance, it found that companies that split the roles of chairman and chief executive didn't necessarily generate a greater return on equity.
 But even without this correlation, investors are still willing to give higher valuations to companies that are deemed good citizens. Put another way, investors give some companies with good track records the benefit of the doubt. That may explain in part why Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has lost only about 1 percent of its value this year. A Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary, General Re, was party to a transaction that A.I.G. has said was accounted for improperly.
 Berkshire ''is a company with a culture of accountability, and that resonates with investors,'' said Gavin Anderson, chief executive at GovernanceMetrics International, a firm in New York that grades corporations on governance practices. (It does not have an official rating on Berkshire.)
 Mr. Anderson's firm recently studied the performance of companies that scored its highest rating: 10 on a scale of 1 to 10. Of 3,220 global companies, only about 1 percent received that score. Shares of those companies generated an average annual total return of 15.6 percent over the five years through Feb. 28. By comparison, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 1 percent, annualized. 
 Of course, there is an inherent difficulty in trying to beat the market by choosing companies based on good corporate governance. Governance is just one issue; there are other fundamentals to consider, like earnings growth and profit margins. It's also hard to know that a company that is considered ethical today will seem so in the future.
 And it's important to distinguish between ethical business practices and social responsibility issues. Cases in point are so-called sin stocks, like shares of tobacco, gambling and alcohol companies, which have been on a tear over the last five years while the overall market has been flat. 
 Individual investors face another problem: they generally don't have access to private sector research, like reports from such firms as GovernanceMetrics, whose most basic data package costs $7,500 a year. 
 But at the very least, investors should look for past improper behavior in companies in which they're about to invest, Mr. Anderson said. A quick way, he said, is to run a search of a company's litigation and regulatory infringement history, much of which is available through public databases and the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 ''What we're looking for when we search for this type of information is a pattern,'' he said. ''I would submit to you that if a company has a pattern of constantly being sued for improper business practices, that suggests its culture allows this type of behavior.''
 And that's precisely the type of company that should make an investor wary.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Guess At Stadium Jobs Is Highest Yet

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently provided a new reason for building a 75,000-seat stadium on the Far West Side of Manhattan -- and it's not the Olympics, conventions, or professional football.
 ''Keep in mind that what this is about is jobs, jobs, jobs -- and people need those jobs now,'' Mr. Bloomberg said the day the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted to sell development rights to the Jets so that they can build a $2.2 billion home on the Hudson.
 But the mayor, in his eagerness to become a champion of the working class and draw union support for the project, appears to be exaggerating the number of blue-collar jobs that would be created by the project, according to everyone from the Empire State Development Corporation to the Independent Budget Office and stadium critics. 
 In a burst of enthusiasm, the mayor said the stadium and exhibition hall would generate 7,500 permanent jobs. The Jets claim only 6,971, but that is still more than the combined payrolls at Giants Stadium -- the team's current home in the Meadowlands in New Jersey -- the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and Madison Square Garden, the busiest arena in the country.
 The state's general project plan for the proposed stadium estimates that a more modest 3,110 new jobs -- 45 percent of what the Jets claim -- will flow from the operation of the stadium and spending by visitors who attend Super Bowls, basketball games, concerts and trade shows there.
 The Independent Budget Office put the projected number of jobs at 3,791, a bit higher than the estimate by the state, which supports the project.
 Most National Football League stadiums schedule only 10 games each season, including two exhibitions. But the Jets contend that their stadium will be full much of the year with other sporting events, conventions, special events, ice skating shows and circuses. Still, the hot dog sellers, ushers and security guards, and the Teamsters who put up and take down exhibit booths, are not full-time workers.
 ''Typically, a stadium generates seasonal part-time low-wage jobs, although these will be union,'' said Robert A. Baade, a leading sports economist, who teaches at Lake Forest College. ''This is not a very efficient public works program. Someone has to ask, 'Is this good public policy, or not?'''
 Under the terms of the Jets deal with the city and the state, taxpayers would contribute at least $600 million toward the cost of what the Jets are calling the New York Sports and Convention Center. That would translate into a subsidy of $86,070 per job if the Jets projections are correct, or more than $190,000 per job if the state is right.
 Job projections are as much art as science, and the different results in this case arise from the fact that the Jets used an economic simulation model that was different from the one the Empire State Development Corporation and the Independent Budget Office used.
 The Jets acknowledge that the job numbers are wildly at odds. But, they say, the state and the budget office, along with the Jets, all say that the stadium will have an enormous economic impact. 
 ''Although the methodologies are different,'' Thad Sheely, the Jets vice president of development said, ''the conclusions are the same in the sense that this project will generate tens of millions of dollars in economic impact and thousands of jobs.''
 The state's analysis is certainly in line with the Jets, who say that the project will generate $72.5 million a year in state and city taxes, roughly $30 million more than it will cost the city and the state to subsidize it. But both the city and the state largely used the economic impact numbers produced by the team's consultant, Ernst & Young, according to state and city officials involved in the analysis.
 The I.B.O., however, was much more cautious, conducting its own analysis and concluding that the stadium would produce a $210 million fiscal surplus over 31 years, or only about one-fifth of what the Jets claim.
 None of the studies compared the impact of the stadium to alternative proposals in which government invested $600 million in public money in affordable housing, transportation projects, or job development on the piers in Red Hook. Some community groups and critics of the stadium say that kind of analysis would have put the stadium into some kind of perspective as to what is the city's best investment.
 In any event, the mayor and the Jets have won vociferous support from construction unions in the city. The reasoning is simple. The number of construction jobs in the city fell to 111,100 last year from a high of 122,000 in 2001, although the industry now appears to be on the rebound.
 ''We want jobs,'' Edward J. Malloy, president of the 100,000 member Building and Construction Trades Council, told a March 30 rally of several thousand construction workers. ''The only real way of creating long-term, sustainable jobs on the West Side of Manhattan is to move forward with the New York Sports and Convention Center.''
 But once again there are widely varying estimates of just how many construction jobs there will be. The mayor and the Jets contend that the project will generate 18,000 jobs. It actually means, the Jets acknowledge, that there will be an average of 4,500 jobs during the four years of construction.
 The budget office's estimate, however, was far lower than the Jets' -- an average of 2,880 construction jobs per year, and it did not bother multiplying that figure by four, because construction jobs by their nature are temporary.
 The state, in turn, came up with a higher number, 3,188, but still 1,300 shy of the Jets.
 The community and civic groups who opposed the stadium may have missed an opportunity to win union support when they failed to discuss job opportunities associated with their alternative to the stadium--building housing.
 Instead, the Jets capitalized on the issue, pledging not only to employ union workers, but also to ensure that a quarter of the workforce is black, Hispanic or women. That may not be as hard to achieve today as it was 10 or 20 years ago, given that minorities now make up 51 percent of the construction workers in New York City, according to the census.
 ''More than half our new members coming into apprenticeship programs are minorities who live in the city,'' said Paul Fernandes, chief of staff at the Building and Construction Trades Council. ''It's really one of the higher-paying blue-collar jobs you can get in the city, because there's no more manufacturing.''
 But Jim Haughton, who heads an organization that has fought discrimination in the construction industry for 40 years, said that far too many black union members are out of work today.
 ''There's nothing wrong with building the stadium,'' he said, ''but first things first. You could create thousands and thousands of jobs if you fixed up the infrastructure.''


CORRECTION-DATE: April 13, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the number of jobs that could be generated by a Jets stadium on the Far West Side of Manhattan suggested that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's estimate -- 7,500 -- was an exaggeration. That suggestion was based on more conservative estimates from other supporters of a stadium, including the Jets and the Empire State Development Corporation, and from budget watchdogs, like the city's Independent Budget Office. 
 While the article included comment from other parties to explain the discrepancies, The Times should have also asked the mayor's office for its response. On Monday evening, Edward Skyler, a mayoral spokesman, denied that the mayor's estimate was an exaggeration. He attributed the discrepancies to differences in the parties' methodology and in their assumptions about the number of special events and conventions that would be held at the stadium.

HEADLINE: Hit Man

BYLINE: By Michael Agger. 
Michael Agger is an associate editor at Slate.

 BODY:

CUT AND RUN
By Ridley Pearson.
368 pp. Hyperion. $23.95.
 Ridley Pearson writes best-selling crime novels. He's a best-selling kind of guy. He plays bass guitar in a band with other best-selling authors like Stephen King and Amy Tan, and he recently collaborated with the best-selling columnist Dave Barry on a children's book, ''Peter and the Starcatchers,'' a prequel to ''Peter Pan'' that quickly became a best seller. Like many successful people, he divides his time between locations, in this case St. Louis and Idaho. (Which, when you think about it, is more of a best-selling author state than, say, Montana, which has been overrun with sensitive midlist writers.) On his personal Web site, Pearson relates that a young adult novel is scheduled for publication in September, and he also details his various projects in television and film. About his poetry, he remains coy.
 While Pearson may be a cross-platform modern content provider, his crime novels remain his core business. It's a good moment for the genre, as we live in a restless era. Presumably there are readers out there who enjoy strolling through the mind of a serial killer while sitting at home on an old couch surrounded by sunlight. But the crime novel thrives in airports, on commuter trains and among the treadmill rows. (It also does well on audiotape.) A Pearson book would not be my first choice for an extended stay in a cabin in the permafrost. On a 22-hour plane ride to Tokyo, however, Pearson would be my man.
 Pearson's latest novel, ''Cut and Run,'' is what is known in the trade as a ''stand-alone.'' Urged on by their publishing houses, crime writers tend to write series. They introduce a character, and if the audience is there, they can extend the run for 6 or 17 more books. Pearson's original success was the continuing Lou Boldt-Daphne Matthews series, which is based in the Pacific Northwest and draws its momentum from the romantic tension between the main characters. But when a crime writer tires of his creations he will sometimes produce a new set of sleuths -- hence, the ''stand-alone,'' a venture into virgin territory and a chance to increase the readerly flock.
 The hero and potential franchise player of ''Cut and Run'' is Roland Larson, a federal marshal who dates on the job. He begins an affair with the witness he's protecting, Hope Stevens, a computer expert who has the goods on the Romeros, a secretive family involved in Medicare fraud. Some of the best contemporary crime writers introduce us to a particular milieu -- George Pelecanos, for example, who sets his novels in the African-American byways of Washington. In ''Cut and Run,'' Pearson's characters inhabit a generic world that you might call thrillerland, a place of violent weather (''The fall night air slapped him''), postcard-worthy locations and daft reasoning: if you need to track down your lost lover, concentrate on cities that offer performances of Shakespeare. She always loved Shakespeare. 
 Flimsy logic like this is what we expect, and it does not impair the enjoyment, or the escapism, of ''Cut and Run.'' Pearson designs his plots with the simplicity of a ball drop. Larson must protect Hope from an assassin who razors up his victims and also recover Penny, the daughter he never knew he had. The action set pieces unfurl with declarative ease, and the closest Pearson ever comes to pointless exposition is to relate that Penny likes ''Gogurts, pancakes and flank steak,'' none of which play a later role in the story. With its narrative economy and rock-'em-sock-'em encounters, ''Cut and Run'' is not all that different from a modern action movie, except in one major respect: the sex scene. What has become a chaste fade to black in the cinema remains, on the page, a heaving rhapsody. In print, the stars get naked.
 What, then, is the secret of Pearson's best-selling success? He's a storyteller, meaning that he's ruthless, trimming anything that distracts. He's also winningly conventional. The crime novel, for all its clinical descriptions of murder, is at heart a conservative entertainment. It excites and plays upon our fear of death, but it rarely introduces any real existential panic or sorrow. Especially in Pearson's hands. Sure, the heroine's Blackberry will chime at precisely the wrong moment, but we know that in the end the killer will be caught, that justice will be served, and that the hero will arrange it so that the little girl gets the dog she wanted. Every so often, the reader gets what he or she wants too: a little comfort food for the mind.
