HEADLINE: Striking Gold in Acres of Brownfields

BYLINE: By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: LYNDHURST 

 BODY:
ON a cloudy spring morning, workmen spread dark sludge across a large swath of flat ground, a former landfill in the middle of the Meadowlands. Nearby, a steady stream of workers arrived with their truckbeds filled with large chunks of concrete, wood and other discarded construction materials, ready to dump onto the site. 
 The sludge had been dredged from the bottom of Newark Bay, the construction debris left from another development site. Add several million more tons of fill, enclose it and the base is ready for four golf courses and several thousand homes, shops and offices -- all expected to rise from this sprawling site in the shadow of the Manhattan skyline.
 The Meadowlands Golf Project is the most ambitious undertaking of Cherokee Investment Partners, which in the last five years has come to dominate the development landscape of New Jersey. The North Carolina-based equity firm, which specializes in developing contaminated sites, has hundreds of millions of dollars of projects planned for every corner of the state -- from the Meadowlands to Elizabeth, Bayonne and Carteret, and from Camden to Pennsauken to Asbury Park. 
 With 10 to 15 percent of its more than $1 billion in investments tied up in New Jersey, the state has become the single most important component in Cherokee's portfolio. 
 Offering to do what state and local municipalities say they cannot -- clean up and redevelop former industrial sites, known as brownfields -- Cherokee has been welcomed by officials eager to turn contaminated, revenue-draining stretches of land into upscale, tax-producing communities while at the same time assuming the potentially costly liability.
 ''They're taking on some fairly challenging projects,'' said Bradley M. Campbell, commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. ''Their willingness to take risks can advance our policy goals.''
 Yet not every official is ready to turn over the keys to the city or the state to an obscure out-of-state company whose track record offers little evidence of what to expect.
 In the Meadowlands, complaints lodged by some residents have led Cherokee to alter the scope of its design and delay plans for a second phase. In Camden, homeowners have filed a court petition to block Cherokee from razing 1,200 homes in the Cramer Hill neighborhood and replacing them with 5,700 new ones intended for affluent buyers. And in Pennsauken, environmental advocates are fighting Cherokee's plan to condemn and develop an industrialized island in the middle of the Delaware River where a pair of eagles have nested.
 What is in the minds of many observers -- from environmental activists to homeowners -- is how a former brick-manufacturing company from North Carolina gained such a foothold in New Jersey in so short a time. On its face, the answer is smart business. 

Expertise and Skilled Consultants
 With expertise in an emerging market and sophisticated leveraged financing, Cherokee has tapped into a state peppered with contaminated former industrial sites, where opportunities are boundless and a commitment to ''smart growth'' has encouraged development in densely populated areas. In addition, the company has enlisted some of the state's most skilled consultants to help guide it through the web of local, state and federal rules and programs available for environmental cleanup.
 ''New Jersey has made a state-level policy decision: 'We want to work with brownfields developers,''' Tom Darden, the 50-year-old chief executive of Cherokee, said in a telephone interview from North Carolina.
 As Mr. Darden acknowledged, ''If you added all the investments we have made and intend to make, New Jersey would be our biggest investment area.'' 
 But for those who are skeptical of the kind of large-scale developments Cherokee proposes, a cloudier picture emerges. By taking advantage of legislation that favors development over preservation, availing itself of government subsidies, appealing to strapped municipalities, and donating generously to local, county and state political candidates and parties -- either directly or through well-connected consultants -- Cherokee finds itself not only with preferred status, but also in a position to affect many of the state's most important land decisions.
 ''Any time somebody dominates a specific industry, they have influence beyond what I think of as appropriate,'' said Andrew Willner, executive director of the New York-New Jersey Baykeeper.
 Mr. Willner said by putting together the capital and the right experts, Cherokee ''has gotten some very interesting contracts.''
 Although the company tries to maintain a low profile, some projects have attracted a great deal of attention, not only from opponents but also from the United States attorney's office, which according to the state's senior environmental official is looking into Cherokee's role in the death of an endangered species of eagle at its Pennsauken project.
 Rich Ochab, spokesman for Cherokee, said the company ''recently became aware that the U.S. attorney has been looking into the facts regarding Petty's Island.''
 ''We have offered to help and be cooperative,'' he said, ''and the investigators have taken us up on that offer.''
 With control over more than 3,200 acres of the state's most developable land, Cherokee has several multimillion-dollar undertakings on the drawing board:
 The Meadowlands Golf Project, a $1 billion development encompassing golf courses, nearly 2,000 homes and a hotel, office and retail complex on former landfill in Rutherford, Lyndhurst and East Arlington.
 A 470-acre site in Bayonne (38 acres of which are a former landfill) to be converted into an 18-hole golf course.
 A $1.2 billion redevelopment of 450 acres in the Cramer Hill neighborhood of Camden where new homes, a golf course and a marina are envisioned.
 In Pennsauken, just north of Camden, another $1 billion plan for 2,700 homes, a marina and a golf course on Petty's Island as well as along several miles of riverfront. 
 It also has 30 acres of land in Elizabeth, where a marina is planned to provide ferry service to Manhattan as well as 275 acres of land the company remediated in Woodbridge and Carteret and recently sold to a developer. And it has committed $30 million in a $1.2 billion shorefront redevelopment scheduled for Asbury Park.
 Yet of all the projects begun or contemplated in New Jersey, the only one that is completed is the Jersey Gardens Mall, opened in 1999, where Cherokee turned what was the Elizabeth city dump into a 1.3-million-square-foot shopping mall.

Low-Key but High-Powered
 Despite its ubiquitous presence in New Jersey -- the firm's offices in the state are on the eighth floor of a building in East Rutherford overlooking the Meadowlands -- most residents have never heard of Cherokee, a fact that does not bother its officers. ''We don't want to be in the papers,'' said William Gauger, president of Cherokee Northeast. ''That's not who we are.''
 So what, then, is Cherokee?
 The company, which promotes itself as the world's leading investor in brownfields redevelopment, was formed in 1984, when Mr. Darden joined in the purchase of four brick plants in North Carolina, forming the Cherokee Sanford Group -- variously described as the largest privately held brick company in North America.
 About two years later, soil contaminated with petroleum was discovered at the company's plant in Sanford, N.C. Rather than take the soil to a landfill, Mr. Darden received state approval to mix the soil with uncontaminated clay to make bricks, in the process burning out the contaminants through combustion in the kilns. With that, the company entered into the business of removing contaminated soil from gasoline stations and using it to make bricks. 
 Before long, Cherokee saw the potential in buying businesses with pollution problems, cleaning them up and either running or selling them -- setting the template for today's operation. Changing its name to Cherokee Environmental, the company began investing in real estate, mostly contaminated land in densely populated regions.
 Initial capital came from individual investors, who, like Mr. Darden, were part of Raleigh's entrepreneurial community. Needing more capital to invest in real estate, Cherokee closed on its first $50 million venture capital fund in 1996, backed by a Kansas-based chemical company, Koch Industries. That was followed by a second private equity fund of $250 million in 1998, and then a venture fund, which closed in 2003, with $620 million in commitments. The majority of those investment funds come from large pension plans and university endowments, with about $20 million coming from 40 private investors, Mr. Darden said. 
 Critics of Cherokee -- who insist that company has been given preferential treatment in the granting of contracts in New Jersey -- have speculated that some of those private investors are part of the state's ruling political elite, an accusation that Mr. Darden denied.
 ''Nobody who is currently in New Jersey or involved in politics there has invested in us,'' he said. As a privately held company, Cherokee is not required by law to disclose the identities of its investors.

'More Juice' Than Tropicana
 Jeff Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, is skeptical. ''Being smart politically only gets you so far,'' he said. ''You have to have something to trade on, some juice. What buys them the juice they have? They have more juice in New Jersey than Tropicana.''
 While Cherokee's lists of financial backers are closed to the public, the company's political contributions, and those of its leading consultants, are a matter of public record. Since 2000, Cherokee, its affiliate companies and individual officers have contributed more than $267,000 to political parties and individuals in the state, records show, about half of which were donations to the Democratic State Committee. 
 Mr. Darden dismissed the notion that the company was trying to buy favors through its political donations, and said that some of the Cherokee's projects had started under a Republican administration.
 ''Do people who are involved in the political process do it to buy influence?'' Mr. Darden asked. ''Or do they do it to get to know and meet people whom they respect? For me, that's it.''
 Nevertheless, when the company raised money for its third equity fund, Mr. Darden said, he added a provision barring the use of investor money for political contributions, noting that the appearance of conflicts could be ''too controversial.'' Still, company officers can make their own donations.
 Nor did the provision stop the company from hiring some of the state's best-connected consultants to help push its projects at the local and state level. For instance, DeCotiis, FitzPatrick, Cole & Wisler -- consistently named one of the state's most influential law firms -- handles Cherokee's legal affairs in New Jersey. Robert DeCotiis was legal counsel to Gov. Jim Florio, and his son, Michael, held the same post under Gov. James E. McGreevey. 
 For lobbying and public relations, Cherokee turned to Winning Strategies, a company headed by Jim McQueeny, a former chief of staff to Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, whose partners include Richard Gannon, a former top aide to Mr. Florio, Senator Lautenberg and Senator Bill Bradley; and Brad Brewster, former executive director and counsel to the New Jersey Assembly. Princeton Public Affairs, founded by Dale Florio (no relation to the governor), who was a top adviser to Gov. Christie Whitman, is also helping with public relations.

Cherokee's Political Donations
 Mr. Darden said that when Cherokee first comes into a state, it seeks out the best consultants in the area. ''If it turns out that the firm is politically connected, then it is what it is,'' Mr. Darden said. ''New Jersey tends to be a state with lots of politics going on.''
 Cherokee's balance sheets reflect that phenomenon. When the political donations made by the organizations listed as ''Cherokee consulting team'' are added to the mix, contributions to state and local candidates as well as party organizations in New Jersey alone total $1.5 million in the last four years. While these consulting firms represent numerous clients, the implicit role they play on behalf of Cherokee makes some critics uncomfortable.
 ''We're looking at an iceberg here and we're only seeing the top third -- the consultants they hire, the connections they have,'' said Mr. Tittel of the Sierra Club. ''We don't know what's going on in the bottom two thirds.''
 Besides raising capital, Cherokee's main expertise lies in remediation. After a site has been rendered usable, it sells the project's various elements to developers, who put up housing, retail space or recreational facilities. In the last 15 years, Cherokee has acquired about 350 such properties in the United States, Canada and England, which are in various stages of redevelopment, a company spokesman said.
 In terms of major redevelopment efforts, Cherokee has projects under way in Denver; Charleston, S.C.; and Richmond, Calif., as well as in New Jersey. But for now, completed projects are far more limited in scope than anything on the drawing board -- a pair of golf courses in Houston, a research and office park in San Francisco and a 30-acre mixed-use project in the company's hometown, Raleigh.
 ''It's a valid observation that what we have built here is unfortunately a smaller sample size than what we would like,'' said Mr. Darden, explaining that the company's investment rate has been greater recently, and that the big projects take at least 10 years to complete.
 Those major projects -- with billion-dollar price tags -- have gone a long way toward impressing local officials eager to be relieved of any potential liability at brownfield sites. But in reality, these billion-dollar figures represent what the projects will be worth once the houses are built and sold, the hotel and retail operations are producing income and the golf courses are collecting greens fees. 
 Even Mr. Darden admits the numbers are somewhat elusive. ''I have no idea what it all adds up to,'' he said.
 As for actual investment on Cherokee's part, the figures are more modest. The company spends about $45 million a year on remediation, Mr. Darden said. 
 Moreover, as brownfield redevelopers, Cherokee has access to government financing not typically available to commercial developers. The company has made an art form of piecing together public support through the use of discounted purchase prices (because the land is contaminated or because a municipality has acquired the property through eminent domain), grants for site investigation and infrastructure upgrades, state-backed financing, and reimbursements of up to 75 percent of the cleanup cost. 
 ''Cherokee has certainly taken advantage of the model of state subsidies available for brownfields cleanup,'' Mr. Willner said.
 Without such public support, said Mr. Gauger of Cherokee Northeast, these projects would not be possible.

No Apologies From Cherokee
 ''I'm not apologetic for taking advantage of legislation that existed before these projects were even a glimmer in my eye,'' he said. ''If the state doesn't become a financial partner and help you, the projects don't happen.''
 Cherokee's largest endeavor to date -- the Meadowlands Golf Project -- illustrates how the company works within the system.
 With Manhattan to the east and Giants Stadium to the north, Mr. Gauger stood in a parking lot last May to break ground on a 1,230-acre redevelopment site that if completed would enclose six landfills and encompass six golf courses, almost 3,500 homes, two resort hotels and a commercial center. Standing at his side was Governor McGreevey, who hailed the project as a prime example of his ''smart growth'' policies, and Susan Bass Levin, commissioner of community affairs and chairwoman of the New Jersey Meadowlands Commission.
 Four years earlier, in 2000, Governor Whitman had presided over a ceremony at the same site, naming EnCap Golf, a Cherokee company, as the chosen developer and praising the plan as an opportunity to turn around decades of abuse.
 ''For many years, the Meadowlands was looked upon as nothing more than a piece of water and mud, with no value except to be dumped on,'' said Robert R. Ceberio, executive director of the Meadowlands Commission. 
 But in 1998, the state approved the Brownfield Remediation Act, intended to provide financial incentives to private companies to clean up and develop contaminated sites. The same year, the Meadowlands Commission put out a request for proposals to remediate and redevelop the wetlands, and EnCap Golf was one of nine groups of development teams to respond. Based on Cherokee's completion of two golf courses in Houston and its impressive fiscal profile, the company was chosen for the project. 
 Mr. Ceberio said the other applicants, which included Starwood Heller, PMK Group and Corcoran Jennison Companies, ''didn't have any work in that field.''
 By 2000, EnCap executives predicted golf would be played there in 2005, but the latest projections put that at 2009 or 2010, a delay that Mr. Gauger attributes to the 80 to 90 public hearings.

Money for Remediation
 ''It takes a lot of time,'' he said. ''You're not just convincing one group of government. You need to convince many groups of government. It's torturous.'' 
 In addition to making its way through the regulatory process, Cherokee has spent a good deal of time securing agreements with state and local authorities on the cost of remediating and redeveloping the site.
 For instance, Phase 1 of the Meadowlands project calls for capping, or enclosing, four landfills -- in Rutherford, Lyndhurst and North Arlington -- and building four golf courses, 1,980 homes, 750 hotel rooms, and 850,000 square feet of office and retail space. But in North Arlington, residents for months expressed deep concerns over the likelihood of more traffic and the size of the retail and residential portions of Phase 2, which would add two more golf courses. The reaction led Cherokee first to scale back the heights of the buildings and, more recently, to delay the second phase indefinitely. 
 EnCap bought the land from the Meadowlands Commission for $8 million, and Mr. Gauger estimated the cleanup cost of Phase 1 at $150 million, plus $100 million to move radio towers out of the way of some greens. 
 To help EnCap buy the land and pay for the cleanup, the state's Economic Development Authority sold $145 million in low-interest tax-exempt bonds in 2001 -- one of the largest loans ever arranged by the development authority. In addition, EnCap put up a $99 million security bond, backed by American International Group.
 Upon completion of the project, EnCap is to receive $138 million in reimbursements under the state's brownfields program -- close to four times that of any other remediation reimbursement from the state. And by accepting waste material from other projects to fill in its site, Cherokee stands to benefit handsomely from the private sector. 
 The first layer of fill will be treated dredge from Newark Bay, for which the Army Corps of Engineers will pay Cherokee a tipping fee from $40 million to $140 million. The second layer is construction debris that could earn Cherokee $75 million simply for taking it off other builders' hands. The next layer will consist of sludge from the Passaic County Sewage Authority, giving Cherokee an additional $5 million, plus a discount rate on treatment of future waste. The top layer will be an impervious cap with drainage pipes to capture leaking contaminants.
 But to Mr. Tittel of the Sierra Club, this layering leaves nothing but a ''toxic wedding cake,'' and he has criticized the state for allowing an increased number of housing units to be built at the site -- up from 1,400 to 1,980 now planned for Phase 1.
 ''They're putting 2,000 homes on an area where a landfill is,'' Mr. Tittel said. ''Under everything you've got clay and wetlands, which are not stable, and will crack the cap. It costs a lot to remove contaminated soil, but in New Jersey, they've moved to capping because you can get away with it.''
 Dismissing Mr. Tittel's concerns about the cap's stability, Mr. Gauger said Cherokee was going far beyond what was required, noting that while many contaminated sites have only 2 feet of capping, this site will have close to 20 feet.
 ''I don't think anybody has cut us any breaks,'' Mr. Gauger said. ''Could we have done more? Yeah, but it would have resulted in more development. It's always possible to do more but at what point does it become irrational.''
 But Michael Guarino, a former Bergen County health director, said he was incensed by misconceptions about EnCap's largesse, especially the plan for the Bergen County Utilities Authority to transfer control of its former waste station to EnCap.
 The goal is to erase more than $96 million in debt owed by the authority. To pay off the debt, the Meadowlands Commission will pay $18.5 million; Bergen County, $20 million; the state, $11.5 million; the utilities authority, $23 million, and EnCap, $23 million.

Cherokee's Claims Questioned
 Reading from an article on the Meadowlands Commission's Web site, Mr. Guarino said: '''As outlined by the state and EnCap officials, most of the project would be privately funded.' That's how this project got off the ground, through lies.''
 Mr. Guarino, a longtime resident of Lyndhurst, said he was also angered by the agreement his town struck with Cherokee, exempting the company from paying Lyndhurst 39.5 percent of the taxes it would have paid the town on improvements. Late last year, EnCap announced an agreement to sell Pulte Homes development rights on the residential portion of the project for $155 million. With houses starting at $350,000, and other projections of how much this cluster is expected to generate in taxes, Mr. Guarino estimated EnCap could save $600 million in taxes over the 30-year agreement. 
 ''To come to Lyndhurst and say, 'We need money,' that's outrageous,'' he said. ''If they're taking all this public money, there's got to be some accountability. But nobody wants to say anything.''

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 17 about Cherokee Investment Partners and its role in redeveloping several former industrial sites in New Jersey -- the first of two parts -- included an incorrect estimate of fees that Cherokee received for accepting dredge from the Army Corps of Engineers. From information provided by the corps that it pays $10 to $35 a cubic yard to dispose of the material, the article concluded that Cherokee would receive $40 million to $140 million for four million cubic yards of dredge. A contract shows that the corps has agreed to pay the company $5 a cubic yard. 
 The second article, on April 24, about the redevelopment of Pennsauken and Petty's Island, the site of a former Citgo petroleum refinery, quoted the island's environmental manager for Citgo, Jack McCrossin. By his account, a lawyer for Citgo said that when the company approached Cherokee to ask about the eagles, the lawyer was told, ''If the governor wants Petty's Island developed, it will get developed.'' A lawyer for Cherokee, Eric Wisler, denies that he or the company made the comment. 
 In each case, in fairness, The Times should have given Cherokee an opportunity to comment. 
 In addition, the April 24 article suggested erroneously that a falconry expert working for Cherokee needed state and federal permission before observing two bald eagles on Petty's Island. No such permission is required.
 Because of an editing error, the article said incorrectly that the National Wildlife Refuge System -- to whom Citgo was offering the land in exchange for sparing it millions of dollars in cleanup costs in other parts of the state --had not acquired land in New Jersey since the early 1990's. While the system has not acquired new tracts in recent years, it has indeed added acreage to its current holdings.

HEADLINE: Football? Nah, Hardball

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
''I didn't see the light,'' George Zoffinger finally said, ''but I felt the heat.''
 In making his stark admission, George Zoffinger, the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, was referring to the events that unfolded from Trenton to the Meadowlands last week, culminating with the announcement that the state and the New York Giants -- after months of angst and acrimony -- had agreed to build a new $750 million football stadium. 
 Yet in finally yielding to pressure from acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, the combative Mr. Zoffinger -- a millionaire banker and real estate executive -- could not help asserting: ''This is a deal that's being negotiated by the governor. Everyone knows what my stance is and I haven't changed it.'' 
 Mr. Zoffinger's surrender was an appropriately strange end to one of the strangest negotiations in memory, in which the governor used every means at his disposal to prevail not upon the executives of the storied National Football League franchise -- who were seeking a more profitable arrangement with the state -- but on one of his own employees. 
 For the most part, Mr. Zoffinger -- who avoided appearing at the news conference at the Meadowlands where the specifics of the agreement were unveiled -- demurred on the details of his conversations with the governor, the last of which came in the form of a testy cease-and-desist telephone call on Tuesday. 
 Asked about the blunt version of events given by one Giants executive -- ''Codey finally told him to shut up'' -- Mr. Zoffinger chuckled ruefully and said: ''Sure, that's about it. Write it.''
 But even as he tried to show restraint after his scoldings, Mr. Zoffinger could not conceal his disapproval of the eventual outcome, leaving unclear whether he had actually blinked or merely winked at Mr. Codey's demands.
 ''This is not a Zoffinger deal,'' he said.
 Although Mr. Zoffinger declined to spell out his misgivings, he has expressed concerns about burdening taxpayers with new costs of infrastructure and millions in annual debt payments on the old stadium.
 For the governor's part, the agreement to build a new stadium was a major triumph, and the fulfillment of one of his main objectives since inheriting the office last November from James McGreevey, whose administration chased three other professional sports franchises out of the Meadowlands. 
 Under the agreement announced at last Thursday's news conference, the Giants will pay the cost of construction plus $6.3 million in annual rent. Mr. Codey all but broke into an end-zone dance and gushed, ''That will keep the Giants here in New Jersey, where they belong.''
 Standing next to the Giants owners, Wellington and John Mara and Steven and Robert Tisch, as well as Carl Goldberg, chairman of the sports authority, the governor said that when he came into office, he wanted to make the Meadowlands sports complex ''not only economically viable, but a symbol of pride for our state.'' 
 In getting the Giants to build their own stadium -- one where they will be committed to play for at least the next 40 years -- Mr. Codey clearly felt that he had achieved both his goals. 
 ''This is the best deal for the taxpayers of any stadium deal in the N.F.L.,'' he said.
 The clash between Mr. Zoffinger and Mr. Codey -- and the governor's eventual victory in the test of wills -- was a long time in the making.
 Mr. Zoffinger, who was appointed by Mr. McGreevey in March 2002, has made it clear throughout his tenure that his goal was to remake the sports authority into a profitable entity, pushing for commercial development in the form of a $1.3 billion development called Xanadu -- a five-million-square-foot retail, entertainment, hotel and office complex featuring a chocolate waterfall, artificial ski slope and paintball range -- and taking a tough negotiating line against the resident sports teams.
 For his part, Mr. Zoffinger frequently advocated other commercial uses for the Meadowlands, and said that the sports teams -- beneficiaries of what he deemed overly generous deals subsidized by the state -- generated a relatively poor return for taxpayers.
 But Mr. Codey had other ideas when he moved into the State House last November. As an unabashed sports fan who saw professional franchises as an integral part of New Jersey's independent identity, Mr. Codey reacted with visceral horror to plans by the Jets, Devils, Nets and MetroStars to abandon their homes, and made it a priority to preserve the Meadowlands as a ''sports mecca.'' 
 ''We've lost too many teams,'' the governor complained last week. 
 As for the role Mr. Zoffinger has played, the governor said with a mixture of anger and wonder: ''He has essentially presided over the destruction of the sports authority. The purpose of the sports authority was to bring sports teams to New Jersey, and they're all leaving.''
 For Mr. Codey, the most important of these tenants was the Giants, who ushered in the entire professional sports industry in New Jersey with their groundbreaking move from New York in the 1970's. 
 But the Giants, who were already dissatisfied with their 29-year-old stadium, were further upset by the prospect of playing next to what they considered to be a glorified shopping mall -- with all of the attendant traffic congestion on game days.
 ''As a result of the Giants' coming over here, we built a whole new economy then an arena,'' Mr. Codey said. ''As a result, Bergen County and that whole region in the state has grown tremendously. We're losing that?''
 Yet it was only in recent weeks that the tension between the governor and the independent sports authority president rose considerably. Mr. Codey took to criticizing Mr. Zoffinger, privately and publicly, for embarking on ''an adventure'' in his pursuit of Xanadu -- which has already begun going up in the parking lot of the Continental Airlines Arena -- without the Giants' approval. 
 Worse, from Mr. Codey's perspective, Mr. Zoffinger effectively undermined the state's efforts to reach a bargain with the Giants over issues concerning parking, traffic and future tax obligations by maintaining his own more-hawkish negotiating stance.
 Indeed, in the days preceding last Thursday's announcement, Mr. Codey -- who occupies the most constitutionally powerful governorship in the country -- found it necessary to point out that he was in charge.
 Responding to a reporter's question about the Giants' claims that they were dealing with contradictory negotiators for the state, the governor said with more than a hint of annoyance: ''They're dealing with me, and that's that. Everything else is just a distraction.''
 In an end run worthy of the sport in question, the state's negotiating team --the governor; his counsel, Paul Fader; and the chief executive of the sports authority, Mr. Goldberg -- forged an agreement without Mr. Zoffinger. 
 The Giants were openly pointing to Mr. Zoffinger as the chief obstacle to an accord among themselves, the state and the developers of Xanadu, the Mills Corporation and Mack-Cali.
 ''My impression is that George Zoffinger doesn't want this deal to go through,'' John Mara, the Giants executive vice president, had said earlier in the week.
 Another Giants official even suggested that the governor fire Mr. Zoffinger, a step that Mr. Codey said last week he ''hasn't thought about and doesn't want to get into.'' 
 (The fact is, it would not necessarily be simple for Mr. Codey to fire Mr. Zoffinger from his $195,000-a-year position since he serves at the pleasure of the sports authority's board of commissioners.)
 But Mr. Zoffinger, a former state commerce commissioner, resisted what he considered a sweetheart deal for the Giants right up until he received the phone call from the governor last Tuesday. Soon after that, he had enough.
 Mr. Zoffinger said that there would still be plenty for him to do at the sports authority, including shepherding through the completion of Xanadu, traffic improvements and a rail link to the Meadowlands and increasing the profitability of the concert business and racing at the Meadowlands race track.
 And Mr. Zoffinger, using an Italian-American expression, said he took solace in the notion that he got a better deal ''from being a skootch,'' attributing the Giants' eventual concession on the more than $6 million dollars in rent to his peskiness as a negotiator. 
 But in the end, Mr. Zoffinger could not really pretend to be happy about the resolution of the dispute.
 ''The details of this deal will come out,'' he said, ''and the people will decide for themselves.''
 For the time being, Mr. Zoffinger's reservations must take a back seat as Mr. Codey celebrates his landmark day for New Jersey. Still, the good feeling went only so far.
 Asked after the announcement whether, given the new long-term commitment to the Meadowlands, the New York Giants would consider changing their name to include New Jersey, a team official responded with a one-word e-mail message: ''No.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: George Zoffinger, executive director of the sports authority, left, finally yielded to acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, far left, by backing off his opposition to replace Giants Stadium, above. (Photos by Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times, above, and Associated Press)(pg. 5)

SECTION: Section 8; Column 1; Sports Desk; OLYMPICS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 807 words

HEADLINE: Smaller Sports Could Get Some Big Help

BYLINE: By LYNN ZINSER

 BODY:
Trying to win the hearts of the International Olympic Committee members before they vote for the 2012 host city in July, New York's bid leaders are appealing to their wallets by offering free marketing assistance to every international sports federation for the seven years leading up to the Games.
 Daniel L. Doctoroff, deputy mayor and founder of NYC2012, will unveil this inducement today alongside Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at a gathering of sports federation leaders and some I.O.C. members in Berlin. Doctoroff said he hoped this would become a powerful argument for New York, particularly for sports that attract little attention in the United States outside the Olympics.
 The announcement comes as the five bid cities -- New York, Paris, London, Madrid and Moscow -- make presentations today at one of the last large meetings of members before the entire 117-member committee convenes in Singapore for the selection on July 6. The Berlin event includes an I.O.C. executive board meeting and a major international sports convention. About 20 to 25 I.O.C. members are expected to attend. 
 London officials say they also have a major announcement planned.
 Doctoroff will detail his proposed sports marketing council, which would have N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern as the chairman. For every international sports federation that expresses interest, NYC2012 will offer free assistance from people at New York-based companies who Doctoroff said he had enlisted as volunteers. Each federation would be given office space in the organizing committee headquarters and access to experts in marketing, sponsorship and event promotion.
 ''It's an opportunity to help these sports outside of the period of the Olympics,'' Stern said Friday in a telephone interview. ''I think it is a very imaginative thing for the bid team to do. I was happy to help when asked.''
 The initiative aims to appeal to the self-interest of I.O.C. members, most of whom have allegiance to a particular sport. Most federations cannot afford high-powered marketing teams. They rely on the Games to highlight their sports, but it is often the only television exposure they get in the United States. Even the International Association of Athletics Federations has said it wants to increase its American presence despite track and field's popularity during the Olympics.
 ''For most of the sports, and I think you could say maybe all but four or so, we here in the United States represent a largely untapped market that previous Games in the U.S. have failed to capitalize on,'' Doctoroff said. ''We think there is an enormous opportunity for sports like track and field. If you read the I.A.A.F.'s strategic plan, they clearly identify this gap, the United States question, as the most important strategic imperative.''
 NYC2012 has been using the city's concentration of corporate power as a selling point in its bid -- trumpeting that seven of the world's 10 largest advertising companies are based in New York -- but this is its first specific proposal.
 The goal is to set New York apart from its European competitors with its economic advantages and appeal to I.O.C. voters, who are overwhelmingly from Europe. At one time, bid cities did this by lavishing voting members with gifts, trips and personal favors. In the wake of the Salt Lake City bribery scandal, the inducements have to help Olympic sports, not merely line members' pockets.
 NYC2012's idea grew from its planners' meetings with international federation officials, many of whom expressed frustration at not being able to expand their sports in the United States.
 ''Most bid cities are so overwhelmed just getting the venues ready and organizing the Games that they don't take time to promote the sports,'' said Jim Easton, head of the International Archery Federation and one of the United States' three I.O.C. members. ''Maybe they do it for the elite athletes, but they don't appeal to the average sportsman who would like to have a new sport to try.''
 Easton said three archery ranges were built outside Los Angeles before the 1984 Games, spawning club-level participation and crowds that filled the 4,500-seat archery site each day of the Games. Easton said the ranges were still used.
 ''Imagine if you can do that kind of thing in New York,'' he said.
 Stern, who has promoted the N.B.A. internationally, said the key to cracking a new market was identifying current fans and potential fans, concentrating on ways to reach them and approaching sponsors interested in them.
 ''Not everybody is going to get huge TV ratings,'' he said. ''But in New York City, there are loyal and devoted participants and fans in all kinds of sports, and that is valuable to these sports.''
 NYC2012 has timed the announcement for maximum impact, when bid leaders believe the I.O.C. begins seriously considering its choices.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; FICTION CHRONICLE; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 1121 words

BYLINE: By James Parker. 
James Parker lives in Brookline, Mass. He is the author of ''Turned On: A Biography of Henry Rollins.''

 BODY:

PRIME. By Poppy Z. Brite. (Three Rivers Press, paper, $13.95.) This is Brite's third novel about the gay New Orleans chefs Rickey and G-man -- partners in business and love -- and we are told that she is at work on a fourth. Can the franchise sustain itself? The answer is yes. To begin with, a high-end restaurant is -- for any competent novelist -- a gift that keeps on giving. The heat, the bickerings and intrigue, the pursuit of perfection, the dodgy money keeping it all afloat: the setting spawns plots. Further, the gentle G-man and his more highly strung partner, Rickey, are distinct but mutually dependent characters, fervently monogamous but with a restlessness in their relationship that keeps things moving. Here, the boys are knocked off balance when their restaurant, Liquor, is given a terrible review, then maintained in their disequilibrium by a curious invitation for Rickey to go to to Dallas and help organize the menu of a troubled fellow chef named Cooper. A decayed charmer and sexual predator, Cooper is a figure of some interest; his palate may still be acute, but his taste for life has coarsened. His rueful but too forgiving sense of himself and his collapsible morals are well caught by Brite.
 With Rickey anxiously marooned in Dallas, fending off Cooper, and G-man bossing the kitchen at Liquor, the plot thickens in an unhurried way, and the city of New Orleans -- always a major character -- displays its corrupt and generous heart. Economically written, with only occasional lapses into the blandly ornate style we'll call menu prose -- ''this veal cheek in front of him, shredding at his fork's touch like a tiny pot roast, caressing his tongue with its deep, gelatinous texture and flavor'' -- ''Prime'' is saved from being mere canny careerist fiction by the pleasing complexity of the characters.

THE OPTIMISTS. By Andrew Miller. (Harcourt, $24.) Clem Glass, photojournalist, is living in London in a state of calamitous aftermath; an atrocity he witnessed while on assignment in Africa has emptied his life of meaning. ''It was his heart he needed now and his heart had locked fast the night he had straddled the dead with his lenses.'' Shut down, unable to speak about what he has seen, he gives himself over to random big-city drift, going to the movies in the afternoon and bumping about with prostitutes. A call from his father, with the news that his sister, Clare, has been reclaimed by a depression that first engulfed her 20 years before, sets him moving. He travels north to visit his father at a lay Christian community, a place ''neat as a barracks,'' on a small island, where old men pray and grow vegetables. But the religion of this ''remote and elderly man in a corduroy suit'' -- somehow still looming colossally in the psyche of his daughter -- looks like frail protective magic, and is of no use to Clem. Traveling on and scooping his sister up from the clinic, he removes her to a rural cottage where they both attempt recovery.
 ''The Optimists'' is a work of solemn artistry. Miller's style is one of guarded lyricism, in which he allows just enough poetry in the language to get the job done, the mood or moment caught. The sharpest of his senses seems to be his ear. A car engine is turned off in a wood: ''Quietness, like the hissing in a shell, seeped through the skin of the car.'' A long-neglected tap is turned on: ''Yards of old piping juddered, there was a burst of musty air, then the sudden slap of water on the worn enamel.''

NAM-A-RAMA. By Phillip Jennings. (Tom Doherty/Forge, $24.95.) Jennings, who flew more than 300 helicopter missions in Vietnam, has produced in his first novel a work of true American frenzy; it is far too long, and not all the jokes are good (a rogue Cuban agent called Gon Norea?) but ''Nam-a-Rama'' has enough surprise, manic laughter and grisly just-born newness in it to earn comparison to Hunter S. Thompson's ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' and -- more onerously, perhaps -- to Joseph Heller's ''Catch-22.''
 ''Nam-a-Rama,'' like ''Catch-22,'' is a satirical war novel, in which reality has been entirely consumed by a deranged military consciousness and sane men are left alone to nurse their paranoia. Captains Armstrong and Gearheardt, Marine pilots both, are on a shaggy dog of a mission either to assassinate Ho Chi Minh or to make a deal with him -- they aren't sure which. An American starlet called Barbonella parachutes in, topless. At its best Jennings's humor comes down like lightning, fully charged, from some higher and more vital realm; at its least effective, when the page is crowded with pratfalls, improbabilities and silly names, it invites the use of that wilting word ''zany.'' Additionally, some estrangement seems to have occurred between the merry jester responsible for the book's best lines and the distinguished veteran gravely blessing America in the afterword. But this is Jennings's problem, and not the reader's. 

ADIOS HEMINGWAY. By Leonardo Padura Fuentes. (Canongate, $20). Fuentes continues the chronicle of a Havana police detective, Mario Conde, who -- as the novel begins -- is eight years into his second career as a failed writer and part-time seller of rare books. At Finca Vigia, once the Cuban home of Ernest Hemingway (and now a museum dedicated to him), a summer rainstorm has uncovered the bones of a murder victim, a man apparently shot some 40 years before, when Hemingway would have been in residence. Could the killer have been Papa himself? The great man had a ''filthy temper,'' as Conde's former colleague Inspector Manuel Palacios reminds him. The case tempts Conde out of his writerly limbo and into a sort of autumnal transport, in which he revisits the month of October in 1958 at Finca Vigia and watches as a fading Hemingway curses his failing powers, mutters to his dog, exceeds doctor's orders by drinking a whole bottle of Chianti, peers in grumpy perplexity at a copy of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' and curls up with a hypochondriac's treat: ''The Liver and Its Illnesses,'' by H. P. Himsworth.
 Flashing back and forth between 1958 and the present, ''Adios Hemingway'' is an elegantly turned meditation on the cold realities of age, the waning of strength and beauty and the production of literary myth. There is also -- lest the theme should grow too weighty -- some dexterous symbolic work with a pair of Ava Gardner's knickers. Thanks in part to John King's limpid, breezy translation, ''Adios Hemingway'' reads cleanly and feels simple, but in his dreamy and dogged pursuit of Hemingway -- this ''old, rather dirty-bearded man with his large hands and feet'' -- the former Inspector Conde is as psycho-literary a gumshoe as any Paul Auster fan could wish for.


GRAPHIC: Photo: PETER PAUL RUBENS: The Drawings. By Anne-Marie Logan in collaboration with Michiel C. Plomp. (Yale University, $75.) ''Judith Killing Holofernes,'' ca. 1609-10, is the earliest Rubens work to portray the story of Judith from the Apocrypha, in which a pious widow beheads the Assyrian leader and saves her people.

HEADLINE: Rethinking Reconstruction: Grand U.S. Plan Fractures Again

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
For the third time in nine months, the Bush administration has redrafted its project to rebuild Iraq, forcing planners to cancel more of the water, sewage and power plants that were part of the grand American design to transform the shattered country. 
 Many of the halted projects are now described by American officials as ''noncritical'' and ''long term'' because they are scheduled to start two years from now. 
 The need for the reallocation of money grew not only from unanticipated security costs but also from what many experts said were flawed assumptions by Pentagon planners and Congress when they set out to pepper Iraq with large infrastructure projects built by American companies. The latest changes mean less money being spent on building new facilities and more on training and maintenance, with less reliance on expensive Western firms and more on smaller local firms. 
 The redirected funds, together with previous shifts, account for $4.8 billion of the $18.4 billion in aid approved by Congress.
 The administration describes the changes as a natural midstream adjustment. James Dobbins, who has headed reconstruction efforts in Afghanistan and elsewhere, said State Department officials deserved credit for bowing to reality. 
 ''They describe this as a response to changing circumstances,'' said Mr. Dobbins, now with the RAND Corporation in Washington. ''But the shifts are in part a response to a faulty initial strategy.'' 
 When the State Department took over the aid program from the Pentagon last summer, it reallocated $3.46 billion from infrastructure building to meet spiraling security needs, train more Iraqi police officers and start large work programs. 
 In December and again in March, a total of $1.3 billion was shifted from building programs to training, job programs and security, according to a State Department report to Congress issued April 6. 
 The recent changes, the report said with unusual candor, are mainly needed to salvage the facilities already repaired or built, many of which are barely functioning. Iraqis tend to fault poor American planning for the breakdowns while American contractors point the finger at poor Iraqi management. 
 New efforts in training and maintenance are needed, the report said, ''to avoid the shutdown of critical facilities we help rebuild.'' 
 In addition, American aid officials in Iraq now recognize that refurbished electrical and water plants do not help many people until new wiring and pipes are run into individual homes -- less technological but in some ways more arduous tasks. Thus, between poor management of regional grids and chaotic local wiring, urban residents still suffer frequent blackouts even as electrical power capacity climbs. 
 In the case of oil, which provides Iraq with virtually all its revenues, production is lagging despite American spending of well over $2 billion. The northern oil fields are often rendered useless because of insurgent attacks on key pipelines.
 In southern Iraq, oil production is constrained by a breakdown of the system that pressurizes underground petroleum reservoirs with injections of water. The Halliburton subsidiary Kellogg Brown & Root repaired the crucial water plant soon after the main fighting ended in Iraq, at high expense. But the oil fields still receive little water, aid officials report, because the aged pipes carrying water to the oil fields break so often. The Iraqi insurgency, of course, also has caused huge delays. 
 As of March 29, about two-thirds of the $18.4 billion voted by Congress in 2003 had been committed to actual projects, and only $4.2 billion had been disbursed for work completed. Earlier in 2003, the administration spent an additional $2.5 billion of American funds on reconstruction, and the coalition authority also spent billions in Iraqi funds on oil field and other repairs. 
 Contractors have had to devote as much as 25 percent of their spending to security, and construction work often has been halted. 
 Adding to the expense, officials now lament, the contracts signed with international firms allowed them to keep billing the United States for personnel and overhead expenses even when they could not work. The administration is ''shifting work to Iraqi subcontractors that are somewhat less susceptible to insurgency attacks and are not burdened by the same heavy overhead expenses of foreign firms,'' the State Department report said. 
 Rick Barton, an expert in reconstruction at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said the report showed the aid program was adapting, but that it had a hard legacy to overcome.
 ''We started out with a monster master plan that didn't address the need for tangible and quick progress,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Need Turns Aging Strangers Into Roommates

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
In New York, the eternal struggle to cope with the high cost of living has often meant a willingness to live with just about anyone, anyhow.
 Adults in their 30's routinely move back in with their parents. Young artists bunk with other young artists in $3,000-a-month apartments intended for two tenants, not six. Poor immigrants wedge themselves into unsafe tenements, mimicking generations before them.
 But more and more, the unforgiving math of housing economics is altering and upending the lives of older New Yorkers as well, forcing them into urgent partnerships in which embarrassment is eclipsed by necessity, fear must be swallowed and the loves and habits of a lifetime must be bent just to make do -- often with complete strangers. 
 In Queens, Lou Tuccillo, 76, and Billy, 61, never imagined they would suddenly be bound by desperation and forced to split the rent in the way, well, college sophomores more typically might. But the deaths of Lou's wife and Billy's mother conspired to cram the two together in a cluttered apartment in Maspeth.
 In the top floor of a house on Staten Island, Bob Canale, 66, and Tom Block, 62, strangers until last year, are pooling their food stamps, Social Security checks and disability benefits to stay off the streets. Yet out of their later-life crisis -- Bob was assaulted and Tom's heart was weakening -- they have improvised a true friendship.
 Such partnerships are typically accidental, although sometimes anticipated. They can be fleeting or fixed for years. Sometimes, all it takes is a sudden slip on the stairs, and a hospitalization, draining finances and options. Sometimes, all it takes is an eviction notice from a landlord who wants to ride a hot real estate market.
 ''It's hard to be alone, and old, and sick, with very low income,'' said Irena Schafhauser, 77, who fell down the stairs of her four-story walk-up in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a couple of years ago. Unable to continue working at a doctor's office on the Upper East Side, she reluctantly took in Eugene Swierczynski, 57, a neighbor she dislikes.
 ''Before, I was active, but after the accident, I can't ---- '' she started, fighting back sobs. ''I dream a lot, to have something else, but it's very hard, because rent is life.''
 Capturing the doubled-up universe of aging tenants is hard because the arrangements can be short-lived, and because some are reluctant to talk about their circumstances. But according to the 2000 census, more than 9,000 households in the city consisted of people 60 and older, living with unrelated boarders or roommates.
 And with older Americans sometimes waiting years for subsidized housing and people living longer, the trend appears to be growing, according to social workers and lawyers.

Tom and Bob
After an Uneasy Beginning, A Friendship Takes Shape
 When Tom Block lost consciousness after complications from heart surgery a couple of months ago, Bob Canale said, he could not eat, sleep or even go to the bathroom for days.
 ''I love the guy, and he loves me, and we're two straight guys,'' he said then, his voice unsteady. ''I must be cursed, because I don't make friends easy.''
 The two were paired eight months ago by Richmond Senior Services, a nonprofit agency on Staten Island that places needy older people in the same apartment, and usually charges each roommate $500 a month.
 At first, Bob, 66, left, a former caterer who once voted for George Wallace, and Tom, 62, right, a former economics instructor at the College of Staten Island who calls himself a neo-Marxist, did not mix.
 But both men loved Tom's cat, Tigercat. Both had failed marriages. Both had battled personal demons: alcohol for Bob, depression for Tom. Both had survived illegal rooming houses. Soon, each became sensitive to the other's eccentricities and sleep patterns. The two now shop together at the Pathmark, fill up the cabinets without labeling what belongs to whom and talk for hours in the kitchen.
 ''The two of us had very lonely lives,'' Tom said on a recent afternoon.
 ''He used to eat with his cat,'' Bob said.
 ''But now I have Bobby,'' Tom said.
 Fortunately, Tom recently bounced back from his operation and is recuperating at home. And Bob, who was Tom's only visitor at the hospital, has become an unofficial home health aide, cooking him ravioli dinners and running errands.
 Bob is even reading Nietzsche, much to Tom's delight.
 But now, there is the Jim factor. As in Jim, the third roommate, who arrived two months ago. He is friendly enough, Bob and Tom say, but he is so messy that cockroaches have become a problem. So for the first time in nearly eight months, Bob and Tom have to lock their bedrooms, and try, again, to coexist peacefully with a stranger.

Lou and Billy
The Secret to Getting Along: Staying Out of the Way
 At 11 a.m., Lou Tuccillo begins his daily circuit by eating lunch and maybe playing bingo at the Self-Help Maspeth Senior Center.
 At 1 p.m., he visits the library across the street to read the tabloids, and any books or periodicals on jewelry. His nickname, he explains, is Diamond Lou, and he used to own jewelry stores in Queens and Manhattan, as well as a house in the Catskills, before tens of thousands of dollars in medical and funeral bills for his wife depleted him.
 At 2:30 p.m., he orders a coffee at a McDonald's, a few blocks down, and sits at his favorite corner table, alone.
 At 5 p.m., he returns to his $90-a-week room -- actually, it's more of an alcove -- in the apartment he shares with a guy named Billy, who would not give his last name. After a nap and some dinner, he heads to the neighborhood bar before returning at midnight.
 ''I kill my time,'' Lou said. ''I never thought this would happen to me.'' 
 Lou, 76, has spent his twilight years as a boarder in a succession of two-family houses in northwest Queens, surviving on about $800 a month in Social Security benefits. A succession, he explains, because every 10 months or so, his landlord sells the property because the market is so good.
 For Lou, the current arrangement, which he heard about by word of mouth, may be the most trying yet. The place is a mess, he says, choked with clothes, cardboard boxes and discarded food. Lou's clothes always reek of Billy's cigarettes.
 ''Mainly, I'm not there,'' he said. ''It's better for him. It's better for me. We know each other's problems, and what I try to do is stay out of the way.''
 For Billy, 61, the arrangement may have been a blessing in disguise. After his mother died last year, Billy could not afford the $800 rent because it exceeded his disability benefits. But he also found in Lou a generous spirit who cooks London broil or pork chops every Saturday night for the two to share.
 But those routines may soon be upended. Last month, the house was listed for $490,000. So once again, Lou will need to look for shelter. But this time, it will be different, he says, because of Billy.
 ''I'm going to try and take him with me because he don't have no defense at all,'' Lou said. ''If it weren't for me, he'd be homeless.'' 

Edna
At 79, Learning to Live With People Who Aren't Family
 Year after year, person after person, Edna Grabstein's world is shrinking.
 She had three children with her husband, who owned Grabstein's Delicatessen, a well-known establishment in Canarsie, Brooklyn. Then, after he died, she had to declare bankruptcy partly because of a dispute with the deli's new owners.
 The only place she could afford was an apartment on Staten Island in a house owned by her sister, for $700 a month.
 Then, a few months ago, Edna's sister and brother-in-law sold the house and moved to Florida. And the only option Edna had was Richmond Senior Services, even though she had never lived with nonrelatives before.
 Moving day was Dec. 2, and Edna's son, Marty, an actor who is the voice of ''Courage the Cowardly Dog,'' the cartoon character, was there to comfort her. But Edna broke down when the movers threatened to drive off with her possessions until someone came up with cash, not a personal check.
 ''I'm 79,'' she cried. ''It's stressful enough as it is for anyone to move, especially for a 79-year-old woman who didn't expect to be moving at this point in her life.''
 The subsequent transition has not been easy, but Edna calls herself a survivor. One roommate, Louise, complained that Edna's television was too loud. The other, Mary, apparently smoked in her room, against house rules.
 Mary left in January; her bedroom remains vacant. Edna and Louise barely speak to each other. But at least Edna has her old couch to keep her company.
 ''I've sat there, just to touch home again,'' she said.

Helena
Home Is Half a Dining Room Until a Boarder's Luck Turns
 Helena Dziedzic came to America in 1990 from Poland to live with her daughter and grandson. But after quarreling with her daughter, she found herself alone in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with no money and no English skills.
 Helena ended up receiving public assistance and paying about $200 a month to live in the dining room of a one-bedroom apartment with four or five other Polish immigrants. Or, to be more precise, half the dining room, since there was a flimsy curtain that separated Helena's bed from the main pathway to the kitchen and the bathroom.
 Every morning for more than four years, Helena, now 75, was startled by the cadences of people cooking, showering and eating just a few feet away. Every night, she was unable to sleep, as tenants came and went at all hours, turning on the light and opening the refrigerator at the foot of her bed. 
 But last year, her roommates wanted to get rid of Helena.
 ''They want to kick me out for a bigger table,'' she said during a visit in November.
 Desperate, she contacted the Polish and Slavic Center, a social service agency, and Jacek Bikowski, a tenant consultant for the North Brooklyn Development Corporation. With their help, she moved in December into a sunny one-bedroom apartment at a residence for the elderly, Jennings Hall, in Williamsburg. No roommates.
 Helena smiles constantly now, and with her own kitchen, she finally feels comfortable cooking. She is also trying to improve her English, jotting down in Polish the definitions of new words like ''squirrel,'' ''faucet'' and ''quiet.''
 ''It is very nice,'' she said. ''Not noisy. No opening the door. No opening the lights.'' 

Irena and Eugene
Bickering the Days Away, With an Occasional Thaw
 In a scene reminiscent of Sartre's ''No Exit,'' Irena Schafhauser and Eugene Swierczynski, two Polish immigrants, complain about the same things, day after day, from opposite ends of their two-bedroom apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
 There he is, rolling his own cigarettes in the kitchen, reading the Polish magazine Wprost. There she is, sprawled on her bed, her beloved Doberman, Azor, beside her, vials of medicine strewn about.
 ''She's a sick woman,'' Eugene, 57, said one morning. ''I'm a sick man. She lives over there. I live over here. That's it.''
 Before moving in with Irena for $400 a month, Eugene was living in a homeless shelter, battling depression. Before that, he had his own apartment and worked as a carpenter, until he fell off a ladder at a construction site and became disabled.
 Neither goes out much. So they end up bickering. He says she is too short-tempered. She says he drinks too much.
 ''I don't want him,'' said Irena, 77, whose speech has been impaired by a recent stroke. ''Even if somebody pay me less, that's better.''
 Sometimes, detente prevails. If Irena, who takes 15 prescriptions each day, rejects her daily meal delivered by a local service for the elderly, she gives it to Eugene. And Eugene, who is genuinely fond of Azor, has called her ''a nice woman'' on several occasions over the last few months.
 When the two are getting along, they usually talk about how Irena is battling the landlord, who wants to evict them, renovate the rent-regulated apartment and charge someone else more money. About how Irena has fallen behind, again, on her phone and utility payments. About how the government is cutting her benefits to $547 a month from $666, and is pushing Eugene to go to a health clinic he does not want to go to.
 Sometimes, the two silently puff on their cigarettes and stare out the window at the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building, off in the distance. Sometimes, they just sigh.
 ''I want to live by myself again,'' Eugene said. ''But I can't.''

HEADLINE: Sex Shops Expect the Other Stiletto to Drop

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

 BODY:
During the last two years, X-rated shops have made a quiet but pronounced comeback in New York City, with dozens of new businesses opening in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn, Greenwich Village and even near Times Square.
 But strict new zoning rules now reaching the final stage of a nearly yearlong legal battle could force most of them to close, bringing highly visible changes to the neighborhoods in which the stores have clustered.
 ''What they've done is made it impossible for these guys to stay in business,'' said Herald Price Fahringer, the lawyer for a coalition of about 75 video stores and X-rated theaters challenging the restrictions in court. ''If this law were to be upheld, 85 percent of all the stores would have to close.'' 
 Last week a state appellate court upheld the stricter regulations but issued an interim stay of the ruling until later this month, when the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, will consider whether to grant a permanent stay and hear a further appeal. If the stay is not granted, the new rules would go into effect immediately, sewing up loopholes to zoning regulations enacted by the city during the mid-1990's. 
 Under those earlier regulations, stores or clubs that devoted at least 60 percent of their inventory or space to non-X-rated material were not considered ''adult entertainment'' establishments at all, allowing owners who were attentive to the letter of the law to open up sex shops in residential and commercial neighborhoods where they would otherwise have been banned. Strip clubs simply put more space aside for nonsexual entertainment -- one opened a sushi bar -- and video stores offered action thrillers and comedies as well as sex DVD's. 
 The new regulations, said John Feinblatt, the city's criminal justice coordinator, would establish a ''common-sense test'' for whether a business qualifies as a sex shop. Peep shows, signs excluding minors, and other features would all qualify a business as a sex shop and subject it to the more stringent regulations that govern such establishments, he said.
 Under those rules, established in 1995, sex shops are banned from residential and most commercial zones. They are allowed in industrial zones and some commercial ones, including parts of Eighth Avenue, the garment district in Midtown, and the West Side of Manhattan. But there is a catch: No sex shop may sit within 500 feet of another such business, of a zone from which they are prohibited, or of ''sensitive receptors'' like schools or houses of worship.
 Mr. Feinblatt said that should the new regulations go into effect, the city would immediately begin reinspecting sex shops to see if they were in compliance.
 The 500-foot requirement could prove particularly nettlesome for a large number of the stores. On the west side of Eighth Avenue, for example, three stores selling sex videos --Hustler Video Xtremes, Nilupul Video, and DVD Blowout -- occupy a row of storefronts just around the corner from St. Luke's Lutheran Church on 46th Street.
 Farther down Eighth Avenue, on 40th Street, three video stores occupy a single building, No. 300. To the east, in the heart of the garment district, are a number of other sex shops, some of them within a block or so of the Millinery Center Synagogue on the Avenue of the Americas.
 It was in part to crack down on such ''clustering'' -- which some community leaders say drives out potential high-end tenants and retards economic development -- that the 1995 rules were established. 
 ''The problem we really have is the clustering,'' said Barbara Randall, executive director of the Fashion Center Business Improvement District, which has experienced one of the largest growths in sex-themed businesses, in part because many of the side streets in the district are zoned industrial.
 If the new laws are upheld, she noted, the number of such shops will drop significantly. ''Even if we max out on the number of porn places we have in the neighborhood, we'll have far fewer than now, and that would be great,'' Ms. Randall said.
 But it would not be so great for the store owners, some of whom have spent years trying to stay open legally.
 ''They have expended so much money trying to comply with the city's ever-changing regulations,'' said Jaymee Kahn, a lawyer who helps represent Ten's World-Class Cabaret, a strip club on 21st Street, between Park Avenue and Broadway. ''If they say 60/40 isn't good enough, I think my client would be unable to continue to operate.''
 Not all the video stores and strip clubs would be in danger. A few were exempted when the 1995 changes were made. And some stores may move to an industrial zone or comply with the new law, though that would render them all but unrecognizable as sex-themed businesses.
 Mr. Feinblatt, the criminal justice coordinator, said the blocks would change or the stores would. ''That,'' he said, ''translates into a better quality of life for those who live in that neighborhood.''
 At least some owners appear to be preparing for a new regulatory regime. The building at 300 West 40th Street, which houses three X-rated video stores, used to have a fourth. One of its employees, who declined to give his name, said last week at the store that it had switched to selling exclusively mainstream movies about a month ago. 
 But a few minutes later, an employee of a store next door -- who also refused to give his name but said all four establishments had the same owner -- denied that the newly rechristened store had ever sold X-rated material.
 ''It used to be a candy store,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Here's to the Loafers Who Lunch

BYLINE: By ERIKA KINETZ

 BODY:
NEW YORK is a city of professionals and predawn discipline, an empire meant to be conquered not by wanderers but by the lusty achievement of the hyperemployed. Languorous weekday afternoons are the province of those deemed to be lacking in power. 
 Still, a fair portion of the city's employable population can be found, midweek, far from any office, whiling away the hours in restaurants and cafes. Unlike the corps of freelance writers with their laptops, these loiterers do not appear to be engaged in any income-producing work. Call them flaneurs, if you want to romanticize them with a French name. Some are princes of leisure, who clearly have never learned that a bank account may approach zero. Others are conscientious objectors to the rat race, who have decided that their personal freedom is worth more than the compromises that might gain you a flat-screen TV. 
 All of them -- superrich, rich or merely upper middle class -- have somehow inoculated themselves against the fiscal anxiety that drives most unemployed people to try to get a job. And they have enough disposable income to afford the minimum entry (a cup of coffee) into one of the precious places that allows low-revenue loafing. 
 Scattered throughout this alternative ecosystem of cafes, these people off the city grid appear to be upstanding folks with open wallets and nice footwear. But who are they? Why are they not working? And how on earth can they afford those shoes?

Downtown Cipriani

3:30 P.M. ON A WEDNESDAY -- The outside tables at Downtown Cipriani, on West Broadway in SoHo, were packed. Robert Dimin, an artist; Justin Melnick, a young entrepreneur; and Nicole Trunfio, a model, sat inside, around a bottle of Acqua Panna ($9) and lemonades (at $5.50 each).
 Mr. Dimin wore a black baseball cap with an orange Princeton ''P'' pulled low over his forehead. ''It's the only time to come here,'' he said. ''Weekdays, when everyone else is working.''
 Ms. Trunfio got up to leave, and Mr. Melnick walked her out. They stood by his black Vespa, which has custom black matte rims, racing tires and a pipe that makes it sound like a Harley. 
 ''Tomorrow is my birthday,'' Mr. Dimin said. ''I turn 25. That's old.'' He swore he had nothing fabulous planned, just a private party at Lotus.
 ''I view myself as a downtowner,'' said Mr. Dimin, who grew up on the Upper East Side but now lives in Princeton. He said he had studied photography at Parsons but did not graduate. His fiancee, Elizabeth Kessler, is working toward a Ph.D. in archaeology at Princeton University, and he is not, at present, employed. 
 ''I only want to make my own projects,'' he said. ''I get yelled at every day by my family: 'Get a job. Go work for The A.P. Use your skills.' I can't. I have to do it my way.'' 
 He was wearing a black Burberry pique shirt and striking orange Nikes. How could an idealist afford such stuff? ''My $150 Nikes that should have cost $35?'' Mr. Dimin said. ''A lot of gifts. And my art sells for a lot of money.''
 Mr. Dimin's work, shown at CVZ Contemporary, includes photographs of nubile young women and an American flag fashioned of gray-and-blue fatigued cloth -- much like the material of Mr. Dimin's baggy shorts -- and stripes of the same thin Prada red that graces his beat-up wallet. 
 ''I don't like money,'' Mr. Dimin insisted. ''I'm not rich like a lot of people I know, like the 'Born Rich' movie. That's an entirely different ballgame. I'm the poorest kid of the rich kids.'' 
 Mr. Melnick, 24, came back inside and put an NTB herbal cigarette in his mouth, but didn't light it. ''I'm quitting,'' he said. 
 Mr. Melnick, who said he dropped out of the University of Denver to help open a restaurant, explained that he split his time among New York, Los Angeles and Paris, running a nightclub and restaurant consultancy. He is also developing a line of surfer clothing. ''For me the most depressing thing would be to make $10 million and have it be a Von Dutch,'' he said, referring to a popular clothing line.
 He gazed at a photo of the 25-foot climbing wall at his old high school, the White Mountain School, in New Hampshire. ''I wanted to expand the climbing program,'' he said. ''So I raised the 15 grand it cost to build it.'' When pressed for details, Mr. Melnick explained, ''The way my father looked at it was as a tax write-off.'' (School officials said that Mr. Melnick's father contributed $9,000; they raised the rest.)
 The bill for the lemonades, which numbered about 10, was left on the table unexamined. Mr. Melnick simply announced, ''I'm buying.''

Doma

3:00 P.M. ON A FRIDAY -- Doma Cafe and Gallery, on Perry Street, was packed. Lee Bob Black, 31, moved through the place like a prince in his court. He seemed to know a quarter of the 20 people in the cafe.
 He settled briefly by the window to discuss weekend plans with Edwin John Wintle, 43, a former lawyer and author of the coming memoir ''Breakfast With Tiffany.'' ''I wrote a good portion of my first book here,'' said Mr. Wintle, who works part-time. ''If I don't sell another book, I'll be poor in less than six months.'' 
 ''I'm just an unpublished writer,'' Mr. Black said. ''I made a bunch of money at Morgan Stanley, and I haven't worked in a year.'' He said his first literary effort had been rejected by 60 agents. He spent only $1.63 on coffee that afternoon, and his black Skechers looked worn beyond their four months. ''I don't have expensive tastes,'' he said.
 Nearby, at a large wooden table, sat Brian Moore, 35. To look on him is to think ''wage earner.'' Formerly a compensation analyst at Genentech in San Francisco, Mr. Moore had moved to New York seven months earlier to be with his fiancee, a resident at St. Vincent's Hospital. 
 Tired, he said, of PowerPoint and e-mail, he decided to study for a commercial pilot's license, and he spent most of the afternoon hunched over a training manual.
 Waywardness does not sit easily. ''It's a little unnerving,'' he said, referring to his slightly adrift afternoons. ''I've tended to seek steady pay and security. Now I'm going off on an adventure. There are days when I think, 'What am I doing?' Other days I think, 'You only have one life to live.'''
 He's living, in part, off his Genentech stock, but he said he was at a point at which he had to differentiate needs from wants. A flat-panel television? Definitely a want.
 A friend at an investment bank had offered to help find him a job at her company, Mr. Moore said, but he said he cannot conceive of it. ''I'd have to get a $10,000 signing bonus just for the wardrobe,'' he said.

Via Quadronno

3:45 P.M. ON A FRIDAY -- The small tables at Via Quadronno were packed. Paolo Della Puppa, an owner of the restaurant, on East 73rd Street, sat in back, discoursing on the origins of the European cafe and the European coffee, a trajectory that touched on Turks, Yemenis and the Habsburg dynasty.
 Mr. Della Puppa is Italian, and many of his patrons share his European roots. ''American rich, you are a C.E.O., you have no time,'' he said. ''Italian rich, they live like rich people. They go to work at noon. They enjoy life.''
 Via Quadronno is host to a rotating assortment of diplomats, guests of the nearby Carlyle hotel, private-school moms, members of the Agnelli family and the occasional teenager possessed of a black American Express card. 
 Yet Sue Ventura and her husband, Lou, are also regulars. Mrs. Ventura, a student at the New York School of Interior Design, did not enter the world of the $4 afternoon cappuccino until middle age. In 1994 -- in honor of her 40th birthday -- she quit her job as a bond trader after 15 years on Wall Street. ''My liberation,'' she said, beaming. Her husband still works as a senior managing director at Bear Stearns, though he joins her there after work most days.
 Now, instead of eating at her desk, she practices Italian with the staff at Via Quadronno. But stepping out of a life of hyperproductivity, she says, where one's value is as quantifiable as one's trading powers, was as unsettling as it was glorious. 
 She has reconciled herself to slowness. ''Life is fleeting,'' she said. ''You've got to step back every once in a while.''
